title: State v. Stevens
description: The Court reversed a circuit court order revoking appellant's probation, holding that probation cannot be revoked for violation of a non-judicially imposed condition of probation.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				John Marcus Stevens, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Spartanburg County
Â Gordon G. Cooper, Special Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26333
Heard May 2, 2007 - Filed June 4, 2007
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				John Benjamin Aplin, of S.C. Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant contends the circuit court erred in revoking six months of his probation because the revocation was not predicated on appellantâ€™s violation of a condition of probation imposed by the sentencing judge.Â  We agree and reverse the partial revocation.
FACTS
Appellant was on probation following 2002 convictions for stalking and domestic violence of a high and aggravated nature.Â  In 2005, appellant was alleged to have violated certain of his probationary conditions. Furthermore, a woman with whom he had been cohabiting complained to respondent Department of Probation, Parole, and Pardon Services (DPPPS) that while she had ended a romantic relationship with appellant, he â€œrefused to leave her alone.â€Â  In lieu of issuing a probation revocation warrant based upon the alleged violations, DPPPS entered an agreement with appellant in June 2005 whereby appellant consented to participate in DPPPSâ€™ Global Positioning Satellite (GPS) Program.Â  Under this agreement, appellant agreed not only to be electronically monitored, but also to avoid certain â€œexclusion zonesâ€ areas near the former girlfriendâ€™s home and work.Â 
 
In August 2005, DPPPS issued a probation revocation warrant alleging appellant had violated his probation by â€œentering a known exclusion zoneâ€ established by the June 2005 agreement.Â  At the circuit court hearing, appellant argued that the violation of a non-judicially mandated term could not be the basis for a probation revocation.Â  Specifically, appellant argued that such a revocation would violate the separation of powers doctrine as enunciated in State v. Archie, 322 S.C. 135, 470 S.E.2d 380 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The judge revoked six months for appellantâ€™s violation of an exclusion zone.
ISSUE

	Whether the circuit court erred in revoking appellantâ€™s probation where he did not violate a judicially imposed condition?

ANALYSIS
Appellant contends his violation of an exclusion zone established by his GPS agreement with DPPPS cannot be the basis for a probation violation.Â  Under the facts of this case, we agree.
DPPPS acknowledges that revoking appellantâ€™s probation for his violation of a non-judicially imposed term would have violated the separation of powers doctrine under the version of Â§ 24-21-430 in effect when State v. Archie was decided.Â  DPPPS contends, however, that any such constitutional problem was eliminated by a 1996 amendment to the statute.Â  The current version of Â§ 24-21-430 retains the language affirming the sentencing courtâ€™s authority to â€œimposeâ€¦andâ€¦at any time modify the conditions of probationâ€¦â€ but adds these sentences:

	To effectively supervise probationers, the [DPPPS] director shall develop policies and procedures for imposing conditions of supervision on probationers.Â  These conditions may enhance but must not diminish court imposed conditions.

We agree with DPPPS that the statutory change authorizes it to create policies and procedures which implement and support â€œconditions of supervision on probationers.â€ Â (emphasis added).Â  To read the statute as DPPPS urges, however, as authorizing it to add conditions of probation, would render the statute violative of the constitutional requirement of separation of powers.Â  It is well-settled that the determination of those conditions is a judicial function which cannot, consonant with S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 8, be delegated to an executive agency such as DPPPS.Â  State v. Archie, supra.Â  
 
The statute permits DPPPS to impose â€œconditions of supervisionâ€ which â€œenhanceâ€¦court imposed conditionsâ€ of probation.Â  Under the statute, one requirement which a court may impose as a condition of probation is that the probationer â€œsubmit to intensive surveillance which may include surveillance by electronic means.â€Â  Section 24-21-430(11).Â  Where condition 11 is imposed by the court, DPPPS may require the probationer to participate in the GPS program as a condition of supervision under Â§ 24-21-430 because this program would â€œenhanceâ€¦court-imposed conditionsâ€Â  Under these circumstances, a violation of GPS monitoring would be a violation of the â€œenhanced court imposed conditionsâ€ and therefore grounds for a revocation.Â  In this case, however, the sentencing court chose not to require appellant to â€œsubmit to intensive surveillance;â€ DPPPS therefore could not unilaterally impose GPS monitoring on appellant as this method of supervision did not enhance a judicially-ordered condition of probation.Â  Nothing prevented DPPPS and appellant from reaching an agreement whereby appellant would participate in the program.Â  While appellantâ€™s failure to abide by the â€œexclusion zoneâ€ was a breach of his agreement with DPPPS, it was not a violation of the conditions of his probation.Â  Under these circumstances, the circuit court erred in revoking a portion of appellantâ€™s probation.
CONCLUSION
The order revoking six months of appellantâ€™s probationary sentence is
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice J. Cordell Maddox, concur.

title: Lee v. Bunch
description: â€œThe Court holds that evidence of plaintiffâ€™s pre-accident alcohol consumption was properly admitted under Rule 403, due to the presence of other evidence to support the defendantâ€™s argument that plaintiffâ€™s alcohol consumption contributed to the accident.  The Court also affirmed the trial courtâ€™s decision to allow defendant to amend his answer, finding no prejudice to the plaintiff.  Finally, the Court reversed the trial courtâ€™s ruling that the original defense verdict on the primary negligence claim and the defense verdict on the loss of consortium claim were inconsistent and reinstated the original defense verdicts on both claims.â€
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				John David Lee and Kathleen Newman Lee, Respondents,
				v.
				Robert Allen Bunch, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Orangeburg County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26334
Heard April 3, 2007 - Filed June 11, 2007Â  
REVERSED IN PART; AFFIRMED IN PART


	
		
			
				Donnell G. Jennings and R. Hawthorne Barrett, both of Turner, Padget, Graham & Laney, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Stephen B. Samuels and Joseph R. Dasta, both of McWhirter, Bellinger & Associates, of Lexington, for Respondents.
			
		
	

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  We granted certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision in Lee v. Bunch, Op. No. 2004-UP-550 (S.C. Ct. App. filed October 27, 2004), in which the court ordered a new trial due to the trial courtâ€™s failure to exclude evidence of plaintiffâ€™s pre-accident alcohol consumption.Â  We reverse the Court of Appeals and reinstate the original jury verdicts in favor of Bunch.
FACTS
This case arises out of a 1997 traffic accident involving John David Lee (Lee) and Robert Allen Bunch (Bunch).Â  The motorcycle driven by Lee hit the driverâ€™s side of Bunchâ€™s automobile, as Bunch was moving perpendicularly across Old Dunbar Road, a two-lane highway in Lexington County.Â  
 
The parties presented conflicting accounts of how the accident happened.Â  Lee claimed that Bunch negligently attempted a U-turn or three-point turn from the right shoulder of the road where his car had been parked, while Bunch testified he was trying to make a left turn from the roadway into the parking lot of his fiancÃ©â€™s place of employment, Johnny Bâ€™s Bar and Grill.Â  The parties also disputed the time of the accident, with Bunch claiming the collision occurred at â€œdusk-darkâ€[1] and Lee contending it occurred around 10:30 p.m.Â  
 
Lee suffered numerous broken bones, a head injury, and a severe groin injury as a result of the accident.Â  Trooper P.A. Nelson of the South Carolina Highway Patrol was the investigating officer and met with Lee later that night in the emergency room.Â  During their conversation, Trooper Nelson smelled alcohol on Lee and requested a blood sample be drawn.Â  The test conducted by SLED indicated Lee had a blood alcohol level of 0.036%.
At a pre-trial hearing, Lee moved to exclude any evidence of his alcohol consumption.Â  The trial court denied the motion, finding Leeâ€™s alcohol consumption would be probative as to the determination of liability.[2]Â   
Lee later testified that he left a family birthday party at Murrayâ€™s Bar and Grill shortly before the accident occurred.Â  He recalled having two liquor drinks along with dinner.Â  Lee stated he was on his way to the Skyline Club, a bar and dance hall, when he collided with Bunch.Â  After Leeâ€™s testimony, Bunch moved to amend his answer to include the affirmative defense of comparative negligence.Â  The trial court later granted the motion.Â  
 
The jury returned a defense verdict, assigning 70% of the fault to Lee and 30% to Bunch.Â  The jury also returned a verdict in favor of Bunch on Mrs. Leeâ€™s loss of consortium claim.Â  The trial court ruled that the verdicts were inconsistent because Mrs. Lee was entitled to recover damages due to the juryâ€™s finding that Bunch was partially negligent.[3]Â  The trial judge then instructed the jury to determine some amount of damages for Mrs. Lee.Â  After deliberating again, the jury awarded a total of $9,000.00 to Mrs. Lee.Â  
 
Each party appealed to the Court of Appeals.Â  The Court of Appeals reversed the trial courtâ€™s decision to allow evidence of Leeâ€™s pre-accident alcohol consumption and remanded for a new trial.Â  The Court of Appeals did not address the other issues raised by Bunch or Mrs. Lee.
ISSUE
Did the Court of Appeals err in reversing the trial courtâ€™s decision to allow evidence of Leeâ€™s pre-accident alcohol consumption?
ANALYSIS
The trial court analyzed the admissibility of the alcohol evidence under Rule 403, SCRE.Â  An appellate court reviews Rule 403 rulings pursuant to an abuse of discretion standard and gives great deference to the trial court.Â  State v. Myers, 359 S.C. 40, 48, 596 S.E.2d 488, 492 (2004).Â  See also State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 378, 580 S.E.2d 785, 794 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œA trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding the comparative probative value and prejudicial effect of evidence should be reversed only in exceptional circumstances.â€).
The Court of Appeals found that the probative value of Leeâ€™s alcohol consumption was at best, slight.Â  The court focused on the fact that Leeâ€™s blood alcohol level was under the legal limit pursuant to the driving under the influence (DUI) statute.[4]Â  Furthermore, the Court of Appeals emphasized that no specific evidence was presented to show Leeâ€™s impairment.Â  
 
Although Leeâ€™s blood alcohol level did not implicate a criminal DUI offense, testimony of Bunchâ€™s experts constituted probative evidence of Leeâ€™s impairment that arguably contributed to the accident.Â  Bunchâ€™s experts, relying on the blood alcohol level of 0.036% taken several hours after the accident occurred, estimated that Leeâ€™s blood alcohol level at the time of the collision was closer to 0.066%-0.096%. Â At that level, according to Bunchâ€™s experts, Leeâ€™s alcohol consumption would have negatively affected Leeâ€™s judgment and his ability to multi-task, thus impairing his motorcycle driving skills.Â 
 
Other evidence tended to show Lee was carelessly operating his motorcycle when the accident occurred.Â  An eyewitness to the accident, Chong Abernathy, estimated Leeâ€™s speed at 40-45 miles per hour, which was five to ten miles per hours over the posted limit on that road.Â  In addition, Trooper Nelson concluded that the impact occurred left of the center line.Â 
 
Because there is evidence that supports Bunchâ€™s argument that alcohol affected Leeâ€™s ability to safely operate his motorcycle, this case differs from Kennedy v. Griffin, 358 S.C. 122, 595 S.E.2d 248 (Ct. App. 2004), which was relied upon by the Court of Appeals.Â  In Kennedy, the Court of Appeals held that evidence of the mere presence of marijuana in the plaintiffâ€™s system, without further indication of impairment, could mislead the jury and should have been excluded under Rule 403.Â  In this case, however, Lee admitted drinking shortly before the accident and there was additional proof of impairment, albeit by inference.Â  See Gulledge v. McLaughlin, 328 S.C. 504, 492 S.E.2d 816 (Ct. App. 1997) (holding blood alcohol level relevant and thus admissible because corroborating evidence, including circumstances of accident, supported claim that driver was impaired).Â Â  
 
The expert evidence concerning Leeâ€™s potential impairment, coupled with evidence of speeding and a point of impact left of the center line, supports the trial courtâ€™s decision to deny Leeâ€™s motion to exclude alcohol evidence under Rule 403, SCRE.Â  The circumstances surrounding Bunchâ€™s version of the accident, i.e. that Lee inexplicably ran into Bunchâ€™s automobile, would be more probable if Lee was impaired.Â  Even though the admission of alcohol evidence was prejudicial to Lee, the prejudice did not substantially outweigh the probative value of the alcohol evidence in determining fault.Â 
 
Accordingly, the trial court did not abuse its discretion by refusing to deny Leeâ€™s motion under Rule 403, SCRE.Â  The Court of Appeals erred in reversing the trial court and ordering a new trial.Â  Because the parties raised additional issues which were not addressed by the Court of Appeals, we briefly address those issues.
Amendment of Bunchâ€™s Answer
Lee argues the trial court erred in allowing Bunch to amend his answer to include the affirmative defense of comparative negligence.Â  We disagree.
At a pre-trial hearing, the trial court ruled that Bunch would be permitted to introduce evidence of Leeâ€™s alcohol consumption.Â  On the second day of trial and after Leeâ€™s testimony, Bunch moved to amend his answer to assert the affirmative defense of comparative negligence.Â  The trial court later heard arguments on the motion and then granted the motion to amend, citing a lack of prejudice to the plaintiffs.
The failure to plead an affirmative defense is deemed a waiver of the right to assert it.Â  Whitehead v. State, 352 S.C. 215, 220, 574 S.E.2d 200, 202 (2002).Â  Rule 15(b), SCRCP, provides an exception to the waiver rule by permitting a party to amend his pleadings to conform to the evidence.Â  The rule provides:

	When issues not raised by the pleadings are tried by express or implied consent of the parties, they shall be treated in all respects as if they had been raised in the pleadingsâ€¦If evidence is objected to at the trial on the ground that it is not within the issues made by the pleadings, the court may allow the pleadings to be amended and shall do so freely when the presentation of the merits of the action will be subserved thereby and the objecting party fails to satisfy the court that the admission of such evidence would prejudice him in maintaining his action or defense upon the meritsâ€¦

Rule 15(b), SCRCP.Â  The circuit court is to freely grant leave to amend when justice requires, and there is no prejudice to any other party.Â  Harvey v. Strickland, 350 S.C. 303, 313, 566 S.E.2d 529, 535 (2002).Â  A motion to amend is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial judge, and the party opposing the motion has the burden of establishing prejudice.Â  Id. Â Amendments to conform to the proof should be liberally allowed when no prejudice to the opposing party will result.Â  Id.
At trial, the degree of Leeâ€™s fault clearly became an issue in this case.Â  Although Lee did not consent to the introduction of alcohol into the case, Lee never objected to the evidence of his speeding nor his driving left of center.Â  Thus, comparative negligence was tried by implied consent because the parties addressed an issue not raised in the pleadings that later entered the case.Â  See Sunvillas Homeowners Assn., Inc. v. Square D. Co., 301 S.C. 330, 335, 391 S.E.2d 868, 871 (Ct. App. 1990); Fraternal Order of Police v. S.C. Dept. of Revenue, 352 S.C. 420, 435, 574 S.E.2d 717, 725 (2002) (â€œIn order to be tried by implied consent, the issue must have been discussed extensively at trial.â€).Â  
 
The question then becomes whether Lee suffered any prejudice by allowing Bunch to amend his answer to include comparative negligence.Â  Lee argues that even if we find he consented to a trial on comparative negligence, he was still prejudiced by the amendment.Â  We disagree.
The prejudice that would warrant denial of a motion to amend the pleadings is a lack of notice that a new issue is to be tried and a lack of opportunity to refute it.Â  Collins Entertainment, Inc. v. White,Â  363 S.C. 546, 562, 611 S.E.2d 262, 270 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Prejudice occurs when the amendment states a new defense which would require the opposing party to introduce additional or different evidence to prevail in the amended action.Â  Ball v. Canadian Am. Exp. Co., 314 S.C. 272, 275, 442 S.E.2d 620, 622 (Ct. App. 1994).
Although the issue of comparative negligence was not specifically part of the case until after Lee presented his case, there is no indication that Lee would have presented additional or different evidence especially geared towards comparative negligence.Â  First, Lee was well aware that alcohol would be an issue in the case by virtue of the trial courtâ€™s pre-trial hearing, and he undoubtedly attempted to present a case that minimized the effect his alcohol consumption might have in assigning fault.Â  Secondly, Lee claims that he was not allowed to question two eyewitnesses, Greg Jones and Chong Abernathy, concerning excessive speed and driving left of the center line because they had been released from their subpoenas before Bunch amended his answer.Â  However, both Jones and Abernathy testified extensively as to where Bunch and Lee were situated at the time of the accident, and Abernathy was the first witness to mention Leeâ€™s speeding.Â  Finally, Lee presented his own expert witness in rebuttal to counter Bunchâ€™s expert witnesses.Â  Accordingly, Lee has failed to prove prejudice by the amendment of Bunchâ€™s answer to include the defense of comparative negligence.
Inconsistent Verdicts
On Leeâ€™s claim, the jury returned a verdict of comparative negligence, assigning 70% of the fault to Lee and 30% to Bunch.Â  On a separate verdict form, the jury returned a defense verdict in favor of Bunch on Mrs. Leeâ€™s loss of consortium claim.Â  The trial court, over Bunchâ€™s objection, found the verdicts to be inconsistent because the jury found Bunch to be 30% negligent, which would require an award of some amount to Mrs. Lee due to her lack of fault.Â  The trial judge sent Mrs. Leeâ€™s case back to the jury with an instruction that the jury must award some amount other than zero.Â 
 
Bunch contends that the trial court erred in finding inconsistent verdicts and instructing the jury to award some amount of damages to Mrs. Lee.Â  He argues that the original defense verdict on Mrs. Leeâ€™s loss of consortium claim should be reinstated.Â  We agree.
The original verdicts were consistent.Â  In South Carolina, claims for personal injuries and for loss of consortium are separate and distinct.Â  Daves v. Cleary, 355 S.C. 216, 231, 584 S.E.2d 423, 430 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing Graham v. Whitaker, 282 S.C. 393, 397, 321 S.E.2d 40, 43 (1984)). Â Â Moreover, it is not inconsistent for the jury to return a verdict for the injured spouse on the primary claim and a verdict for the defendant on the loss of consortium claim.Â  See Craven v. Cunningham, 292 S.C. 441, 443, 357 S.E.2d 23, 25 (1987) (juryâ€™s award to injured spouse while denying wifeâ€™s consortium claim was consistent because wifeâ€™s claim was contested throughout trial); Burroughs v. Worsham, 352 S.C. 382, 574 S.E.2d 215 (S.C. App. 2002) (â€œ[W]e find this is not sufficient to say that a plaintiffâ€™s verdict on wrongful death and a defense verdict on loss of consortium are inconsistent.â€); Daves, supra (after finding for injured husband on medical malpractice claim, it was not inconsistent for jury to find for defendant on wifeâ€™s consortium claim because â€œthe jury obviously rejected her testimony, as was their prerogative.â€). 
 
If it is proper for the jury to deny a loss of consortium claim when it has found the defendant liable on the primary claim, the jury could consistently return a defense verdict on Mrs. Leeâ€™s consortium claim when it found in favor of the defendant on the primary claim.Â  However, two prior cases have found that a spouse claiming loss of consortium should have been awarded damages by virtue of a verdict in favor of the injured spouse.Â  See Page v. Crisp, 303 S.C. 117, 399 S.E.2d 161 (Ct. App. 1990); Sullivan v. Davis, 317 S.C. 462, 454 S.E.2d 907 (Ct. App. 1995).Â Â  These cases differ from the present case.
In Page and Sullivan, the defendant was liable on the primary claim.Â  Here, the jury determined Bunch was not liable on Leeâ€™s primary negligence claim.Â  As such, Bunch should not be forced to pay all of Mrs. Leeâ€™s damages if he only contributed 30% to the accident.Â  â€œGenerally, a plaintiff spouseâ€™s claim for loss of consortium fails if the impaired spouseâ€™s claim fails, whether the claim is considered separate and independent from the impaired spouseâ€™s claim or derivative in nature.â€Â  41 Am.Jur.2d Husband and Wife Â§ 227 (2007) (citing Smith v. Ridgeway Chem., Inc., 302 S.C. 303, 395 S.E.2d 742 (Ct. App. 1990) (holding husband could not recover on loss of consortium because the jury found that the wife was not entitled to recover on her strict liability claim)).Â  Bunch also contested some of Mrs. Leeâ€™s testimony in regards to her lost wages.Â  See Craven, supra.Â  Accordingly, because the original verdicts were not inconsistent, the trial court erred in re-submitting Mrs. Leeâ€™s consortium claim to the jury.
We address Leeâ€™s remaining issues and affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authorities: Issue 1 (directed verdict/JNOV): Strange v. S.C. Dept. of Hwy. and Pub. Transp., 314 S.C. 427, 445 S.E.2d 439 (1994) (motions for directed verdict and JNOV should be denied where either the evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt); and Issue 2 (jury charge on negligence per se): Keaton ex rel. Foster v. Greenville Hosp. Sys., 334 S.C. 488, 514 S.E.2d 570 (1999) (a jury charge is correct if, when the charge is read as a whole, it contains the correct definition and adequately covers the law).Â  
 
CONCLUSION
We reverse the Court of Appeals and hold that the trial court properly allowed evidence of Leeâ€™s pre-accident alcohol consumption.Â  We also affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision to allow Bunch to amend his answer.Â  Finally, we reverse the trial court and hold that the original defense verdicts in favor of Bunch on both the primary negligence claim and the loss of consortium claim are not inconsistent.Â  Accordingly, we reinstate both verdicts, including the loss of consortium defense verdict in favor of Bunch.
REVERSED IN PART; AFFIRMED IN PART.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.

[1] On cross-examination, Bunch admitted that in his deposition, he recalled the accident occurring in the â€œdaytime.â€Â  However, both in his deposition and at trial, Bunch stated that he was not exactly sure what time the accident happened.
[2] The trial judge stated, â€œI think itâ€™s probative as to the fact as to whether or not [Leeâ€™s] version of the facts is true, because a jury would be wondering, well, why would this guy just run into the side of this car, and if [Bunchâ€™s] version is true, and one possible explanation is, well, heâ€™d been drinking.â€Â  
 
[3] On Mr. Leeâ€™s verdict form the jury answered â€œyesâ€ to the question, â€œDo you find that the defendant was negligent and that his negligence proximately caused the plaintiffâ€™s injuries?â€ 
 
[4] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950 (Supp. 2006).Â  At the time of the accident, the legal blood alcohol limit in South Carolina was 0.10%.

title: Plyler v. Burns
description: This is an appeal from a grant of a motion to dismiss a cause of action brought by a beneficiary of a conservatorship against a county probate court.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Chandler B. Plyler f/k/a Mary C. Burns, 
				Appellant,
				v.
				Michael J. Burns, Laura Burns, Selective Insurance Company of America, South Carolina Retirement Systems, Horry County Probate Court, BB&T Corporation, Ted H. Watts, individually and on behalf of The National Bank of South Carolina, Debbie Ann Dellavecchia, Individually and on behalf of John Doe Mortgage Company, Tracy Leavens, Colony Bank SouthEast-Broxton, The Conway National Bank, First Citizens Bank of South Carolina, SunTrust Banks, Inc., Allen Bailey and Bailey, Patterson, Caddell, Hart & Bailey, P. A.,Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Defendants,
				Of Whom Horry County Probate Court is 
				Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Charleston County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26335
Heard April 4, 2007 - Filed June 11, 2007Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Russell S. Stemke, of Isle of Palms, for Appellant
				Emma Ruth Brittain and Matthew R. Magee, both of Thompson & Henry, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: This is an appeal from a grant of a motion to dismiss a cause of action brought by a beneficiary of a conservatorship against a county probate court.Â  We affirm.

Factual / Procedural Background
In December 1992, Appellant Chandler Plylerâ€™s (â€œPlylerâ€) mother died as a result of complications from surgery.Â  Plyer was fourteen years old at the time of her motherâ€™s death.Â  Because Plyer was a minor, the Horry County Probate Court (â€œHCPCâ€) established a conservatorship to protect Plyerâ€™s interests in the estate benefits she received as a result of her motherâ€™s death.Â  HCPC appointed Michael Burns (â€œBurnsâ€), Plylerâ€™s father, as conservator.Â 
 
Burns initially filed documentation with HCPC estimating the value of the conservatorship estate to be eighty-five thousand dollars ($85,000.00).Â  Burns obtained a bond in that amount and filed it with HCPC.Â  Approximately two months later, Burns filed an initial inventory and appraisal with HCPC indicating the value of the estate to be $85,618.00 which was held in two certificates of deposit.Â  After the first year of the conservatorship, Burns filed an annual accounting showing the value of the conservatorship to be $90,727.84.Â  The second annual accounting reported a conservatorship value of $152,066.84.Â  The third annual accounting reported a conservatorship value of $158,164.29.
After Plyler reached the age of majority, Burns filed a final accounting with HCPC indicating payments on behalf of Plyler in the amount of $43,410.00 and a balance of $118,935.52.Â  Burns indicated that the balance had been distributed to Plyler and provided a notarized receipt to HCPC.Â  Burns filed a petition for discharge and HCPC granted the petition.Â  This terminated the conservatorship.
In 2004, approximately seven years after the termination of the conservatorship, Plyler commenced an action against Burns, HCPC, and several other entities alleging several causes of action, including gross negligence or recklessness in the supervision of her conservatorship, breach of fiduciary duties, and civil conspiracy.Â Â  Specifically, Plyler alleged that she never received the proceeds held for her benefit under the conservatorship managed by Burns, that Burns converted the proceeds for his own benefit, and that HCPC was liable for negligent supervision of the management of her conservatorship.
HCPC filed a motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  In its memorandum in support of the motion to dismiss, HCPC asserted affirmative defenses under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act (â€œTort Claims Actâ€) and that it was protected by common law judicial immunity.Â  After a hearing on the motion, the trial court granted HCPCâ€™s motion to dismiss on the grounds that HCPC was entitled to judicial immunity under both the common law and the Tort Claims Act.Â  Plyler appealed, and this Court certified the case from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  Plyler raises the following issues for review:[1]

	
		
			I. 
			Did the trial court err in 
			granting HCPCâ€™s motion to dismiss on the basis of the common law doctrine of judicial immunity?
 
		
		
			II. 
			Did the trial court err in 
			considering HCPCâ€™s motion to dismiss because HCPC waived its right to assert common law judicial immunity?
 
		
		
			III. 
			Did the trial court err in 
			declining to apply a gross negligence standard in its review of HCPCâ€™s entitlement to immunity pursuant to the Tort Claims Act?Â 
			
		
	


Standard of Review
In deciding a motion to dismiss pursuant to 12(b)(6), SCRCP, the trial court should consider only the allegations set forth on the face of the plaintiffâ€™s complaint.Â  Stiles v. Onorato, 318 S.C. 297, 300, 457 S.E.2d 601, 602 (1995).Â  A 12(b)(6) motion should not be granted if â€œfacts alleged and inferences reasonably deducible therefrom would entitle the plaintiff to any relief on any theory of the case.â€ Id. Â The question is whether, in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, and with every doubt resolved in his behalf, the complaint states any valid claim for relief. Â Toussaint v. Ham, 292 S.C. 415, 416, 357 S.E.2d 8, 9 (1987).Â  Further, the complaint should not be dismissed merely because the court doubts the plaintiff will prevail in the action. Â Id. 


Law / Analysis
I.  Common Law Judicial Immunity
Plyler contends the trial court erred in granting HCPCâ€™s motion to dismiss on the basis of the common law doctrine of judicial immunity.Â  We disagree.
Judicial immunity serves as a bar to litigation against a judicial officer in certain circumstances.Â  Oâ€™Laughlin v. Windham, 330 S.C. 379, 385, 498 S.E.2d 689, 692 (Ct. App. 1998). Â This immunity, however, is not absolute. Â â€œ[J]udges and other officials are not entitled to judicial immunity if: (1) they did not have jurisdiction to act; (2) the act did not serve a judicial function; or (3) the suit is for prospective, injunctive relief only.â€Â  Faile v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Juvenile Justice, 350 S.C. 315, 324, 566 S.E.2d 536, 541 (2002) (internal citations omitted). 
 
The majority of Plylerâ€™s argument against the application of common law judicial immunity is based on whether HCPC was performing a judicial act when supervising Plylerâ€™s conservatorship estate.Â  Plyler does not dispute the jurisdiction of the probate court.Â  Plyler does, however, contend that her claims against HCPC involve prospective, injunctive relief because she requests an accounting and relief from HCPCâ€™s orders.Â 
 
First, assuming the requested accounting qualifies as injunctive relief, Plyler has made no allegation that HCPC ever possessed any property or money on her behalf.Â  Therefore, the request for an accounting has no application to HCPC.Â  Second, Plylerâ€™s requested relief from HCPCâ€™s orders does not require any injunctive action against HCPC, but instead implies injunctive relief against any of the other defendants seeking to utilize those orders in their defense.Â  Accordingly, the prospective, injunction relief exception to judicial immunity has no application to HCPC.Â 
 
For these reasons, we focus our analysis on the determination of whether HCPC performed a judicial act in supervising the management ofÂ  Plylerâ€™s conservatorship.
In determining whether an act serves a judicial function, the Court must look to the nature and function of the act as opposed to the title of the person committing the act.Â  Id. at 325, 566 S.E.2d at 541.Â  The line must be drawn between acts which are truly judicial and those acts which simply happen to have been performed by a judge.Â  Forrester v. White, 484 U.S. 219, 227 (1988).Â  
 
In Forrester, the United States Supreme Court discussed the difference between â€œjudicial acts and the administrative, legislative, or executive functions that judges may on occasion be assigned by law to perform.â€Â  Id.Â Â  When a court undertakes any adjudicative act within its jurisdiction, regardless of allegations of malicious or corrupt motive, the act is considered a judicial function for which the court will have absolute immunity.Â  Id.Â  However, â€œ[a]dministrative decisions, even though they may be essential to the very functioning of the courts, have not similarly been regarded as judicial acts.â€Â  Id. at 228.Â  Furthermore, judicial immunity has not been applied to a judgeâ€™s action pursuant to rulemaking authority.Â  Id.Â  
 
In South Carolina, the probate court has jurisdiction to determine the need for the protection of the minorâ€™s assets.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-5-402 (2005).Â  Section 62-5-402 provides:

	After the service of notice in a proceeding seeking the appointment of a conservator or other protective order and until termination of the proceeding, the probate court in which the petition is filed has:
	(1) exclusive jurisdiction to determine the need for a conservator or other protective order until the proceedings are terminated;
	(2) exclusive jurisdiction to determine how the estate of the protected person which is subject to the laws of this State must be managed, expended, or distributed to or for the use of the protected person or any of his dependents; and
	(3) concurrent jurisdiction to determine the validity of claims for or against the person or estate of the protected person except as limited by Section 62-5-433.

In the instant case, Plyler alleges that HCPC negligently supervised the management of her conservatorship estate.Â  Plyler contends that the courtâ€™s act of supervising a conservator is fundamentally an administrative act because it requires only the handling of paperwork and other clerical actions.Â  In support of this contention, Plyler relies on the deposition testimony of Burns stating that he rarely discussed the handling of the conservatorship with the judge, he never appeared in the actual courtroom, and he conducted most of his interaction with the staff of the probate court over the phone.
 
Despite Plyerâ€™s contention, the informality of Burnsâ€™ interaction with the probate court is not determinative of the character of the courtâ€™s acts.Â  Although a cursory examination of the relationship between a conservator and the probate court may appear to require only the handling of paperwork, the probate courtâ€™s role is actually much more involved.Â  In accordance with the statutory jurisdiction in Â§ 62-4-502, the probate court has the responsibility to determine whether the conservatorship estate of the minor is effectively â€œmanaged, expended, or distributed to or for the use of the protected person or any of his dependents.â€Â  These determinations involve an adjudication of whether the conservator is acting within the confines of the law with respect to the management of the conservatorship.Â  Such determinations are precisely the type of judicial acts to which immunity applies.Â 
 
Because Plylerâ€™s allegations involving HCPC concern only those acts which would be considered judicial in nature, we find that the trial court did not err in granting HCPCâ€™s motion to dismiss based on common law judicial immunity.
II.  Waiver
Plyler argues the trial court erred in considering HCPCâ€™s motion to dismiss because HCPC waived its right to assert common law judicial immunity.Â  Particularly, Plyler contends that HCPC did not satisfy the pleading requirements for affirmative defenses in accordance with Rule 8(c), SCRCP, because HCPC included the defense of judicial immunity in its memorandum in support of the motion to dismiss, but not in the motion to dismiss itself.Â  We disagree.
Immunity is an affirmative defense which must be pled.Â  Rayfield v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corr., 297 S.C. 95, 105, 374 S.E.2d 910, 915 (Ct. App. 1988); see Rule 8(c), SCRCP.Â  Generally, â€œa failure to plead an affirmative defense is deemed a waiver of the right to assert it.â€Â  Whitehead v. State, 352 S.C. 215, 220, 574 S.E.2d 200, 202 (2002).Â  However, because the aim of this pleading requirement is to avoid surprise defenses, see Rule 8(c), SCRCP note, many courts allow the assertion of affirmative defenses despite a technical failure to comply with the initial pleading requirements where the defense is timely raised to the trial court without resulting in unfair surprise to the opposing party.Â  See Brinkley v. Harbour Recreation Club, 180 F.3d 598, 612 (4th Cir. 1999), abrogated on other grounds by Dessert Palace Inc. v. Costai, 539 U.S. 90 (2003); and Floyd v. Ohio Gen. Ins. Co., 701 F.Supp. 1177, 1187 (D.S.C. 1988).Â  See also Gardner v. Newsome Chevrolet-Buick, Inc., 304 S.C. 328, 404 S.E.2d 200 (1991) (providing that where there are no South Carolina cases directly on point, the Court may look to the construction placed on the corresponding federal rules of civil procedure).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 
This Court has not addressed the issue presented in the instant case, however, the court of appeals decided a similar issue in the case of Wright v. Sparrow, 298 S.C. 469, 470, 381 S.E.2d 503, 504 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  In Wright, the plaintiff argued that the trial court erred in granting summary judgment to the defendant because the notice of the motion failed to specify the particular grounds for the motion.Â  Id.Â  The notice indicated that the motion would be â€œbased on the attached affidavits and memorandum in support of the motion.â€Â  The memorandum in support of the motion set forth the exact bases for the motion.Â  Id. at 471, 381 S.E.2d at 505.Â  The court of appeals found that the trial court properly considered the arguments presented in the summary judgment motion and supporting memorandum despite the defendantâ€™s failure to include the specific grounds in the notice.Â  Id.Â Â Â Â  
 
In the instant case, HCPC timely filed a motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  The motion outlined HCPCâ€™s position that Plylerâ€™s claim was barred by the exceptions to the waiver of sovereign immunity contained in the Tort Claims Act, including the judicial acts exception.Â  The motion did not include the affirmative defense of common law judicial immunity. Â However, HCPC indicated that the grounds for the motion would be more fully discussed in the supporting memorandum.Â  The supporting memorandum detailed the grounds for dismissal included in the motion, and also included the defense of common law judicial immunity.Â  Plyler received the supporting memorandum several days before the hearing.Â 
 
As a practical matter, the analysis of judicial immunity pursuant to both the Tort Claims Act and the common law is substantially similar.Â  See Faile v. South Carolina Dept. of Juvenile Justice, 350 S.C. 315, 566 S.E.2d 536 (2002) (discussing â€œjudicial actâ€ under the common law and the Tort Claims Act).Â Â  Plyler concedes that she received timely notice of HCPCâ€™s assertion of judicial immunity pursuant to the Tort Claims Act.Â  In light of these circumstances, Plyler has not demonstrated that she suffered prejudice or unfair surprise in any way.
Therefore, we find that although HCPC failed to include the affirmative defense of common law judicial immunity in its motion to dismiss, HCPCâ€™s inclusion of the defense in the supporting memorandum was sufficient to comply with the intent of Rule 8(c), SCRCP, in this case.Â Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not err in considering the issue of common law judicial immunity in the hearing on HCPCâ€™s motion to dismiss.Â 
 
Alternatively, Plyler argues that the court erred in failing to grant her a continuance in order to prepare her argument in opposition to HCPC claim of common law judicial immunity.Â  Plyler contends that HCPCâ€™s failure to comply with the time requirements of Rule 6(d), SCRCP, and its failure to comply with the specificity requirements of Rule 7(b)(1), SCRCP, caused her to suffer prejudice and deprived her of due process.Â  We disagree.
The grant or denial of a continuance is within the sound discretion of the trial judge and is reviewable on appeal only when an abuse of discretion appears from the record. Â Bridwell v. Bridwell, 279 S.C. 111, 112, 302 S.E.2d 856, 858 (1983). Moreover, the denial of a motion for a continuance on the ground that counsel has not had time to prepare is rarely disturbed on appeal. Â See State v. Babb, 299 S.C. 451, 385 S.E.2d 827 (1989).
Rule 6(d), SCRCP, provides in part that â€œa written motion . . . and notice of the hearing thereof, shall be served not later than ten days before the time specified for the hearing, unless a different period is fixed by these rules or by an order of the court.â€Â  Additionally, Rule 7(d)(1), SCRCP states that â€œan application to the court for an order shall be by motion which . . . shall state with particularity the grounds therefor.â€Â  However, where noncompliance with the technical requirements of the rules causes no prejudicial effect, failure by the trial court to grant a continuance on that basis is harmless error. McCall v. Finley, 294 S.C. 1, 4, 362 S.E.2d 26, 28 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  
 
Plyler correctly asserts that HCPC did not comply with the technical requirements of Rules 6(d) and 7(b)(1), SCRCP.Â  However, Plylerâ€™s claims that she had insufficient time to prepare for the hearing are misleading.Â  Because the defenses of judicial immunity pursuant to the Tort Claims Act and the common law require similar analysis, and because Plyler received adequate notice of HCPCâ€™s assertion of judicial immunity under the Tort Claims Act, we find that Plyler cannot make the requisite showing of prejudice necessary to reverse the trial courtâ€™s denial of her motion for a continuance.Â Â 
 
Because Plyler suffered no prejudice from HCPCâ€™s assertion of common law judicial immunity in its memorandum in support of its motion to dismiss, the trial court did not err in denying Plylerâ€™s request for a continuance.
 
III.  Tort Claims Act
Plyler argues that the trial court erred in declining to apply a gross negligence standard in its review of HCPCâ€™s entitlement to immunity under the Tort Claims Act.Â  Specifically, Plyler alleges that the trial court should have applied the gross negligence standard contained in S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-78-60(12) and (25) to all exceptions asserted by HCPC.Â Â  We disagree.
The Tort Claims Act provides that â€œthe State, an agency, a political subdivision, and a governmental entity are liable for their torts in the same manner and to the same extent as a private individual under like circumstances, subject to the limitations upon liability and damages, and exemptions from liability and damages contained herein.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§15-78-40 (2005).Â  
 

	The burden of establishing a limitation upon liability or an exception to the waiver of immunity under the Tort Claims Act is upon the governmental entity asserting it as an affirmative defense. Â Provisions establishing limitations upon and exemptions from liability of a governmental entity must be liberally construed in favor of limiting liability.

Steinke v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing and Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 393, 520 S.E.2d 142, 152 (1999).
When a governmental entity asserts an exception to the waiver of immunity and any other applicable exception contains a gross negligence standard, the Court must read the gross negligence standard into all of the exceptions under which the entity seeks immunity.Â  Â See id. at 394, 520 S.E.2d at 153.Â  Gross negligence is defined as â€œthe failure to exercise slight care.â€ Â Id. at 395, 520 S.E.2d at 153.Â  It has also been defined as â€œthe intentional, conscious failure to do something which it is incumbent upon one to do or the doing of a thing intentionally that one ought not to do.â€ Gross negligence â€œis a relative term, and means the absence of care that is necessary under the circumstances.â€ Â Id.Â Â Â Â  
 
HCPC asserted several exceptions to the waiver of immunity contained in the Tort Claims Act, includingÂ  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-78-60(1), (2), and (3) (2005) as a bar to Plylerâ€™s claims.Â  These sections provide that a â€œgovernmental entity is not liable for a loss resulting from: (1) legislative, judicial, or quasi-judicial action or inaction; (2) administrative action or inaction of a legislative, judicial, or quasi-judicial nature; [or] (3) execution, enforcement, or implementation of the orders of any court or execution, enforcement, or lawful implementation of any process.â€Â  Id.
The trial court granted HCPCâ€™s motion to dismiss based in part on these exceptions.Â  Plyer, however, asked the court to consider the additional exceptions contained in S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-78-60(12) and (25).Â  Plyler contends that these sections applied to HCPC and also required the court to apply the gross negligence standard to all other exceptions asserted by HCPC.Â 
 
Section 15-78-60(12) provides an exception to the waiver of immunity where the â€œlicensing powers or functions including, but not limited to, the issuance, denial, suspension, renewal, or revocation of or failure or refusal to issue, deny, suspend, renew, or revoke any permit, license, certificate, approval, registration, order, or similar authority except when the power or function is exercised in a grossly negligent manner.â€Â  Generally, this exception is applied where a governmental agency actually engages in licensing functions.Â  See Steinke, 336 S.C. at 373, 520 S.E.2d at 152 (holding that the Department of Labor, Licensing and Regulation was grossly negligent in failing to revoke a permit at an amusement park).Â  
 
Section 15-78-60(25) provides an exemption to the waiver of immunity where the â€œresponsibility or duty including but not limited to supervision, protection, control, confinement, or custody of any student, patient, prisoner, inmate, or client of any governmental entity, except when the responsibility or duty is exercised in a grossly negligent manner.â€Â  The section is usually applied in situations where a governmental entity is responsible for the actual physical accountability for the person and not merely the personâ€™s interest in property.Â  See Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 341, 585 S.E.2d 281 (2003) (holding the county detention center responsible for the conduct of correctional officers acting in a grossly negligent manner in monitoring an arrestee). 
 
In the instant case, Plyler contends that Â§15-78-60(12) is applicable to the actions of HCPC because the court issued a â€œCertificate of Appointmentâ€ to Burns.Â  Plyler misconstrues the probate courtâ€™s role in issuing the certificate and also erroneously stretches the intention of the statute.Â  The probate court issues a certificate of appointment only after a petition for appointment is filed. Â This petition commences an action where the probate court makes a judicial determination and orders appointment of a conservator.Â  The certificate of appointment is merely the method by which the court effects its order, and is not an issuance of a license or similar instrument.Â  Accordingly, this exception has no applicability to Plylerâ€™s case and should not be utilized as a means to interject a gross negligence standard into the analysis of the issues presented in this case.Â 
 
Section 15-78-60(25), regarding the custody and control of clients, is similarly inapplicable in this situation.Â  The unambiguous language of the statute clearly refers to the protection of the physical person.Â  Plyler makes no claim that the probate court breached any duty to protect her from physical harm.Â  Accordingly, Plyler does not qualify as a â€œclientâ€ pursuant to this provision and therefore may not use it to extend the gross negligence standard to the other provisions of the Tort Claims Act asserted by HCPC.
Therefore, we find that the trial court did not err in declining to apply a gross negligence standard in its review of the exemptions to the waiver of immunity under the Tort Claims Act.

Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision.
MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] We have re-framed the issues presented by Plyler to more concisely conform to the arguments presented in the appellate briefs.Â Â

title: In the Matter of Harriet E. Wilmeth
description: This is an opinion disbarring an attorney from the practice of law.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


	
		
			
				In the Matter of Harriet E. Wilmeth, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26337
Submitted May 15, 2007 - Filed June 11, 2007Â Â  

DISBARRED


	
		
			
				Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Joseph P. Turner, Jr., Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
				
				R. Davis Howser, of Howser, Newman, and Besley, LLC, ofÂ  Columbia, for Respondent.Â 
				
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to disbarment pursuant to Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  Respondent requests the disbarment be made retroactive to the date of her interim suspension.Â  In the Matter of Wilmeth, 368 S.C. 173, 628 S.E.2d 884 (2006).Â  We accept the agreement and disbar respondent from the practice of law in this state.Â  The disbarment shall not be made retroactive to the date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension. Â 
FACTS
The facts set forth below are as reported by the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and are fully sufficient to support respondentâ€™s disbarment from the practice of law in this state.Â  We express no judgment about other pending matters not reflected herein.Â  Â Â Â Â Â 
Matter I
Respondent served as attorney for and, later, as personal representative of two related estates.Â  In connection therewith, the probate judge for Darlington County issued a February 3, 2006 order finding, in effect, that respondent failed to provide competent legal services to the personal representative of those estates, was not diligent in performing her professional services in connection with the estates, overcharged both estates for attorneyâ€™s fees and the personal representativeâ€™s statutory fees, and mishandled the estatesâ€™ tax returns, resulting in the imposition of unnecessary penalties and interest.Â  The probate judge further found that respondent should be required to repay the excessive fees and to reimburse the estates for the tax penalties and interest.Â  
 
More specifically, respondent drafted the wills for two individuals and named herself as alternate and/or substitute personal representative in each of the wills without complying with the provisions of Rule 1.8, RPC, Rule 407, SCACR.Â  After the death of the two individuals, respondent undertook to serve as attorney for each of the estates.Â  When vacancies became available for the position of personal representative, respondent applied for appointment and was appointed as alternate and/or substitute personal representative for both of the estates.Â  Respondent continued to prepare legal documents for the estates.Â  She did not obtain a court order relieving her as counsel for either estate.
Respondent misappropriated $861,367.52 from either one or both of the estates and deposited these funds into an account of one or more entities owned, managed, and controlled by herself or some other bank account chosen by herself, but not in her trust account, and not in a bank account for either estate.Â  On February 17, 2006, the probate court held a hearing to determine the whereabouts of these funds.Â  At the hearing, the probate judge placed respondent under oath and three times asked her to report the location of the funds.Â  Each time, respondent refused to divulge the location of the funds.Â  Thereafter, the judge held respondent in contempt â€œfor removal of the monies from the estate account in question without court approval and failure of [respondent] to provide the court with any information on where the monies are now located.â€Â  The judge sentenced respondent to six months of confinement in the Darlington County Detention Center with a proviso that the contempt could be purged by payment in full to the estate(s).
Respondent was incarcerated.Â  The following day, respondent caused the sum of $861,583.22 to be delivered to the probate court in the form of a check from Mutual Savings Bank, and the judge released respondent from confinement.Â  These funds were not obtained from respondentâ€™s trust account or from the estatesâ€™ bank accounts.Â  Â Â Â Â 
Matter II
Respondent borrowed $4,950,000 from four clients without complying with the requirements of Rule 1.8, RPC, Rule 407, SCACR.Â  The money owed on these four obligations is now past due and owing.Â  Respondent admits that she abused the trust of these clients by borrowing money from them without complying with the Rules of Professional Conduct.Â 
 
Matter III
Respondent closed a real estate transaction and received approximately $160,000 to be disbursed in connection therewith.Â  Respondent failed to make disbursement of the funds as required by the closing documents and, instead, used all or a portion of the funds for her own purposes.Â  The sum of $160,000 had not been disbursed by respondent at the time she was placed on interim suspension and, at that time, her trust account had a balance of only $16,000.Â  The deed related to the transaction had not been signed or recorded in the public records at the time respondent was placed on interim suspension.Â 
 
Matter IV
Respondent served as the closing attorney for a real estate transaction and received approximately $228,000 in funds to be held in trust until disbursed by respondent according to the agreement of the parties to the transaction.Â  Respondent failed to promptly satisfy the first and second mortgages of the sellers of the subject property or to promptly distribute the balance of the sellersâ€™ funds to the persons and entities entitled thereto.Â Â  Approximately six weeks after the closing, respondent paid off the second mortgage on the subject real property.Â  Respondent did not disburse the closing costs of the transaction until approximately three weeks after the closing.Â  As of the date of the execution of the Agreement for Discipline by Consent, respondent had failed to satisfy the first mortgage but had confessed judgment in the matter.Â 
 
On the date on which she was placed on interim suspension, there was a balance of approximately $16,000 in respondentâ€™s trust account.Â  Since the first mortgage had not been paid off, the balance should have been at least $158,000.Â  Instead, the funds had been misappropriated by respondent and used for her own benefit or purpose.Â 
 
On several occasions, parties to this transaction contacted respondent about unpaid items connected with the closing and, when so contacted, respondent gave inaccurate or, at least incomplete, information in an attempt to conceal the fact that she did not have the funds in her trust account from which to make the disbursements provided by the settlement documents.Â  In addition, respondent failed to maintain ledgers or disbursement schedules in connection with this transaction.Â 
 
Matter V
Respondent served as the closing attorney in numerous real estate transactions.Â  She retained monies in these closings to pay the related premiums on the title insurance policies to the title insurance company.Â  The title insurance company discovered 28 missing policy jackets that had been transmitted to respondent but for which she could not account.Â  As a result, the title company revoked its agency agreement with respondent and required her to write a check for the known outstanding premiums due to the title insurance company.Â  Respondent issued a check for $4,100 made payable to the order of the title insurance company.Â  The check was dishonored upon presentment to the bank.Â  The premiums remain due and owing to the title insurance company.Â 
 
Matter VI
Respondent maintained funds in her trust account which belonged to her domestic employee.Â  On numerous occasions, the employee made withdrawals from and deposits into respondentâ€™s trust account.Â 
 
Respondent admits that it was improper to allow her domestic employee access to her trust account. Â In addition, respondent admits that she commingled client funds with non-client funds by maintaining funds which belonged to her employee in her trust account.Â  She further admits that, because of other shortages in her trust account, it is impossible to determine what part of the balance on hand in the trust account belongs to the employee and what part belongs to others who might have a claim against the balance, and that there is a distinct possibility that other persons and entities might have or claim to have an interest in the balance of funds in the trust account that would cause the employee to receive only a small pro-rata amount, if any, of the balance remaining in respondentâ€™s trust account.Â  Â Â Â 
Matter VII
Over a period of time, respondent has repeatedly failed to comply with the money handling and recordkeeping requirements of Rule 1.15, RPC, and Rule 417, SCACR.Â  These failures include not making monthly reconciliations of her trust account and not keeping separate ledgers or records showing funds received and disbursed for each respective client.
LAW
Respondent admits that, by her misconduct, she has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to a client); Rule 1.5 (lawyer shall not charge or collect unreasonable fee); Rule 1.7 (lawyer shall not represent a client if representation involves current conflict of interest); Rule 1.8 (lawyer shall not knowingly acquire a pecuniary interest adverse to a client unless the client consents in writing); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall hold funds belonging to client or third party separate from the lawyerâ€™s own funds; lawyer shall promptly deliver funds to third parties); Rule 5.3 (lawyer shall make reasonable efforts to ensure that the firm has in effect measures giving reasonable assurance that a non-lawyer employeeâ€™s conduct is compatible with the professional obligations of the lawyer); Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(d) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct that is prejudicial to the administration of justice).Â  In addition, respondent admits she failed to comply with the recordkeeping provisions of Rule 417, SCACR .
 
Respondent further admits her misconduct is grounds for discipline under Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct), Rule 7(a)(5) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to engage in conduct tending to pollute administration of justice, bring courts or legal profession into disrepute, or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice law), Rule 7(a)(6) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate oath of office), and Rule 7(a)(7) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to willfully violate a court order).
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and disbar respondent.Â  The disbarment shall not be made retroactive to the date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension. Â Within fifteen (15) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that she has complied with Rule 30 of Rule 413, SCACR, and shall also surrender her Certificate of Admission to the Practice of Law to the Clerk of Court.Â 
 
Within thirty (30) days of the date of this opinion, respondent and ODC shall agree to a restitution plan.Â  In the plan, respondent shall agree to pay restitution to all presently known and/or subsequently identified clients, banks, and other persons and entities who have incurred losses as a result of her misconduct in connection with this matter.Â  Moreover, respondent shall agree to reimburse the Lawyersâ€™ Fund for Client Protection for any claims paid as a result of her misconduct in connection with this matter.Â  The restitution plan shall require respondent to begin paying restitution immediately. Â Respondent shall not be eligible to apply for reinstatement to the practice of law until and unless she demonstrates to the satisfaction of the Court by clear and convincing evidence that she has made full and appropriate restitution.Â 
 
DISBARRED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.Â  WALLER, J., not participating.

title: In the Matter of Harold L. Swafford
description: This is a disciplinary opinion in which the Court publicly reprimands an attorney.
text:
IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


	
		
			
				In the Matter of Harold L. Swafford, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No.Â  26338
Submitted May 15, 2007 - Filed June 11, 2007Â  

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


	
		
			
				Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, Senior Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				William R. Bauer, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and agrees to either an admonition or a public reprimand.Â  We accept the agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
On or about April 11, 2003, respondent closed a real estate transaction.Â  During the closing, the buyer executed a mortgage.Â  Respondent signed as a witness to the execution of the mortgage.
After the closing and outside the presence of the buyer, respondent presented the mortgage to his assistant and requested she also sign as a witness to the execution of the mortgage.Â  The assistant signed the mortgage as requested even though she had not been present during the execution of the mortgage.Â  
 
Respondent then requested his assistant sign a statement under oath in which she attested that she saw the buyer execute the mortgage and that she, along with respondent, had witnessed the execution of the document.Â  The assistant signed the statement and respondent notarized her signature.Â  At the time respondent notarized his assistantâ€™s signature on the statement, he knew the assistant had neither seen the buyer execute the mortgage nor himself witness the execution of the mortgage.Â  Â 
In response to its inquiry, respondent sent ODC a letter dated September 13, 2004, in which he stated all documents at the closing were properly witnessed.Â  At the time respondent sent this letter, he knew the statement was false.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
 
LAW
Respondent admits that by his misconduct he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 4.1 (in the course of representing a client, a lawyer shall not knowingly make a false statement of material fact to a third person); Rule 5.3 (lawyer shall make reasonable efforts to ensure non-lawyer employeeâ€™s conduct is compatible with the professional obligations of the lawyer); and Rule 8.1 (lawyer shall not knowingly make false statement of material fact in connection with a disciplinary matter). Â Respondent acknowledges that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur. WALLER, J., not participating.
