title: In the Matter of Eduardo Curry
description: This is an attorney discipline matter in which the Court imposed a definite suspension.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter of Eduardo Curry, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26340
Heard April 3, 2007 - Filed June 11, 2007Â Â  
DEFINITE SUSPENSION


	
		
			
				Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				Coming B. Gibbs, of Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  This is an attorney discipline case involving two separate instances of misconduct by respondent. Â The Commission on Lawyer Conduct Full Panel (Panel) adopted the report of the sub-panel, which recommended the following sanctions: (1) 30 day suspension; (2) respondent be required to obtain the services of a certified public accountant and an attorney to review compliance with Rule 417, SCACR; (3) respondent must submit affidavits from the CPA and attorney every six months for a period of three years to show compliance with Rule 417, SCACR; and (4) respondent be ordered to pay costs of proceedings.Â  Â  
 
The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) appeals and asks for a harsher sanction, contending the Panel erred in its findings on respondentâ€™s alleged Rule 403, SCACR, violations and in its consideration of certain mitigating circumstances.Â  We agree with ODC and impose a six month suspension and the other conditions recommended by the Panel.
FACTS
This proceeding involves two separate matters arising out of a complaint filed with the Commission in 2002.Â  An investigative panel authorized formal charges in November 2004.Â  The hearing before the sub-panel was held in April 2005, and due to delay in receiving the transcript, the report of the sub-panel was not issued until July 2006.Â  In September 2006, the Panel adopted the report.Â  
 
Matter A
This matter arises from a prior disciplinary action that ended in 2001 with a deferred disciplinary agreement (DDA).Â  The DDA concerned respondentâ€™s failure to obtain Rule 403 certification.Â  A complaint had been filed against respondent for appearing in court without Rule 403 certification, but respondent asserted in 2001 that he had complied with the rule.Â  However, no certification could be found in the Courtâ€™s files.
The DDA prevented respondent from appearing in court without meeting the requirements of Rule 403.Â  It did not order respondent to obtain the trial experiences and certification required by Rule 403, but if he did, respondent was required to file an affidavit and a copy of his compliance certificate with ODC.Â  This agreement was accepted by the Commission on July 20, 2001.
We must now determine whether respondentâ€™s conduct after 2001 violated the terms of his DDA and Rule 403.Â  In an attorney disciplinary proceeding, this Court gives great deference to the recommendation of the Panel.Â  In re Myers, 355 S.C. 1, 584 S.E.2d 357 (2003). Â However, we exercise de novo review of the Panelâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law.Â  Id.

	Rule 403(a), SCACR, provides:
	
		[A]n attorney shall not appear as counsel in any hearing, trial, or deposition in a caseâ€¦until the attorneyâ€™s trial experiences required by this rule have been approved by the Supreme Court.Â  An attorney whose trial experiences have not been approved may appear as counsel if the attorney is accompanied by an attorney whose trial experiences have been approved by this ruleâ€¦and the other attorney is present throughout the hearing, trial, or deposition.
	

Furthermore, we have previously disciplined an attorney for, among other ethical violations, appearing in court without proper certification under Rule 403.Â  In re Moore, 345 S.C. 144, 546 S.E.2d 651 (2001).Â  We noted in Moore that, absent Rule 403 certification, a lawyer is not entitled to â€œappear alone in courts of record in South Carolina.â€Â  Id. at 149, 653.
After the complaint was filed in 2002, ODC reviewed respondentâ€™s file and found no affidavit or certificate of compliance with Rule 403.Â  Upon written inquiry by ODC, respondent responded that he had not completed his Rule 403 requirements and that he had not appeared alone in a trial.Â  Respondent did inform ODC that he was in the process of obtaining certification.Â  However, respondent later admitted that he appeared alone at depositions.
Upon investigation, ODC alleged ethical violations in respondentâ€™s efforts to obtain Rule 403 certification.Â  Several attorneys testified at the sub-panel hearing in regards to this matter.Â 
 
Attorney A testified that he worked as co-counsel with respondent in two cases.Â  However, Attorney A was not aware that respondent lacked Rule 403 certification, that respondent considered his presence to be for the purpose of Rule 403 compliance, nor did respondent ever ask Attorney A to appear specifically as Rule 403 counsel.
Attorney B testified that he appeared with respondent at one or two hearings, two or three guilty pleas, and one deposition.Â  Attorney B was not aware that respondent lacked Rule 403 certification and did not consider his presence to be for respondentâ€™s compliance with Rule 403.Â 
 
Attorney C, respondentâ€™s law partner, testified that he attended numerous hearings, trials, and depositions with respondent for the purpose of acting as respondentâ€™s Rule 403-certified co-counsel.Â  However, Attorney C testified that he sat in the audience and did not participate in the proceedings.Â  He also acknowledged that there were occasions where respondent asked him to go to court and he was not available.
The Panel then identified four different circumstances involving respondent that potentially violated Rule 403 and respondentâ€™s DDA.
The first circumstance identified by the Panel was respondentâ€™s appearance at depositions without a Rule 403-certified attorney.Â  Respondent admitted to appearing alone at depositions but indicated he relied upon the DDA language which only prohibited solo appearances â€œin court.â€Â  The Panel noted that respondent was required to comply with Rule 403, and his failure to insure strict compliance violated the rule.Â  This finding is not in dispute.
The second circumstance was respondentâ€™s appearance alone at status and pre-trial conferences, roll calls, and roster meetings.Â  The Panel concluded that respondentâ€™s conduct did not violate Rule 403 and the DDA.Â  Citing the ambiguity between pre-2000 Rule 403 (â€œactual conduct and trial of a caseâ€), post-2000 Rule 403 (â€œhearing, trial, or depositionâ€), DDA (â€œwill not appear in courtâ€), and In re Moore (â€œcourts of recordâ€), the Panel found that Rule 403 did not specifically prohibit appearances at these types of hearings.
ODC objects to this finding of the Panel.Â  ODC posits that no ambiguity exists because appearances at pretrial and status conferences are appearances in court, which are prohibited by the DDA, Moore, and Rule 403.[1]Â  In addition, ODC contends that even if the rule were unclear, the DDA clearly prohibited appearances in court.Â  We agree with ODC.
Rule 403 (â€œhearingsâ€) and the DDA (â€œwill not appear in courtâ€) clearly encompass respondentâ€™s appearance at pretrial and status conferences.Â  The appearances at these official court proceedings were prohibited by the language of the DDA and Rule 403, and respondent violated the rule and the DDA by appearing in these situations.
The third questionable action identified by the Panel was respondentâ€™s appearances with Rule 403-certified co-counsel.Â  ODC asserted that attendance by co-counsel does not satisfy Rule 403 if the certified counsel is unaware that he is present for purposes of Rule 403.Â  The Panel decided that neither Rule 403 nor prior case law require knowledge by the certified co-counsel of the uncertified attorneyâ€™s lack of Rule 403 certification.Â  The Panel found that it could not rewrite the rule or the DDA to require knowledge by the accompanying attorney, and it concluded that the mere appearance of a certified attorney met respondentâ€™s requirements.
ODC objects to this finding, arguing that the purpose of Rule 403 is defeated if certified co-counsel is unaware that he is considered present pursuant to Rule 403. Â We agree.
 
Respondent admitted he did not inform the attorneys who accompanied him that their presence was needed for compliance with Rule 403.Â  This defeats the purpose of Rule 403.Â  The rule allows an attorney to gain trial experiences by actively participating in court proceedings while in the presence of a certified attorney who is available to assist when necessary.Â  A certified attorneyâ€™s â€œpresenceâ€ means more than mere physical presence; he must be aware of his reason for being present so that he is prepared to aid the uncertified attorney.Â  We find the Panel erred in failing to find respondent in violation of Rule 403 for these appearances when certified counsel was not made aware of the reason for their presence.
The final circumstance involved respondentâ€™s appearances with Attorney C, who knew his presence was for respondentâ€™s compliance with Rule 403.Â  Attorney C admitted that on several occasions he had occupied himself with his own clientsâ€™ business while respondent was in court.Â  The Panel found that Attorney Câ€™s presence and ability to provide guidance if needed, along with his knowledge that he was respondentâ€™s certified co-counsel, complied with the rule and the DDA.
ODC objects to this finding, arguing that the requirement of a Rule 403-certified counsel to be present throughout the proceeding means more than physical presence.Â  ODC argues that if Attorney C occupied himself with his own business, respondent did not have a certified attorney â€œpresentâ€ in the mental sense.Â  We agree.
Much like the certified attorney who is less prepared to assist because he is unaware the attorney is attempting to acquire Rule 403 certification, a certified attorney who tends to his own business is not â€œpresentâ€ for purposes of Rule 403.Â 
 
We find that respondentâ€™s actions in these four situations constituted a willful violation of his prior DDA and Rule 403.
Matter B
This matter arises from a complaint filed by Doctor A, a chiropractor, who treated several of respondentâ€™s clients for injuries related to personal injury claims.Â  Doctor A alleged that respondent failed to pay medical bills on behalf of clients following successful resolution of their cases.Â 
 
Upon receiving notice of Doctor Aâ€™s grievance, respondent issued checks from his trust account for the amounts claimed by Doctor A for each client.Â  Respondent did not review his client files or trust account records before writing the checks.Â  In two cases, respondent issued checks on behalf of clients, yet no funds were held in his trust account for those clients.Â  
 
In two other instances, respondent had not sent checks to Doctor A even though his client ledgers and settlement statements showed that the checks had been written.Â  Additionally, in the nine to ten months between the time respondent allegedly wrote the checks and the time he actually sent the checks to Doctor A, respondentâ€™s trust account balance dropped numerous times below the amount he was holding on behalf of these clients.Â  Respondent claimed he paid Doctor A out of fees earned for other clients but not yet withdrawn from his trust account.Â  After investigation, ODC found numerous violations involving respondentâ€™s trust account and recordkeeping.Â  The findings by the Panel in regards to Matter B are not in dispute.
Upon the commencement of formal proceedings against respondent, he admitted the following: (a) he failed to reconcile his trust account on a monthly basis; (b) he failed to withdraw fees from his trust account when earned; (c) he failed to keep records of earned fees remaining in his trust account; (d) he routinely paid law firm expenses, including payroll, from his trust account; (e) he routinely paid personal expenses, including credit card and phone bills, from his trust account; (f) he failed to maintain an accurate and current accounting journal; and (g) he routinely advanced litigation costs for clients from his trust account when no funds were deposited for that purpose.
 
Respondent violated the following Rules of Professional Conduct found in Rule 407, SCACR, with regard to Matter B: Rule 1.15(a) (lawyers must hold client funds separately and maintain a complete record of those funds); Rule 1.15(b) (possession of funds in which a third party has an interest); Rule 1.3 (diligence); Rule 4.4 (respect for rights of third persons); Rule 5.1 (responsibilities of partner or supervisory lawyer);Â  Rule 5.3 (responsibilities regarding nonlawyer assistants); and Rule 8.1 (misrepresentation in disciplinary matter).Â  The Panel also found violations of Rule 417, SCACR, for respondentâ€™s financial recordkeeping deficiencies.
Mitigating Circumstances
In 2002, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) improperly levied on just over $5,000 from respondentâ€™s trust account for failure to pay quarterly payroll taxes.Â  The IRS should have levied respondentâ€™s operating account.Â  Respondent could not recall when the money was returned.
The Panel noted that respondent had no control over an IRS levy against his trust account, and the Panel viewed the IRS levy as mitigating evidence.Â  ODC objects to this finding, arguing that the negative client balances in the trust account for two of respondentâ€™s clients occurred before the IRS levy and continued after the money was returned.Â  In addition, the IRS levy resulted from respondentâ€™s own failure to pay taxes, and ODC alleges that respondent failed to discover the levy because he did not reconcile his trust account.Â  Finally, ODC contends that respondent should have immediately replenished the missing funds from his trust account with his personal funds.
We believe the erroneous levy by the IRS on respondentâ€™s trust account was unexpected and unpreventable.Â  We keep it in mind when determining a proper sanction.
The Panel also noted the substantial delay in the disciplinary proceedings as evidence of mitigation.Â  The grievance was filed and investigation began in 2002, formal proceedings began in 2004, and the hearing was held in 2005.Â  Due to delays in obtaining the transcript, the sub-panel report was not issued until July 2006.Â  
 
ODC objects to the finding of a substantial delay in the proceedings and challenges the use of such a factor in mitigation.Â  ODC cites the fact that problems concerning respondentâ€™s trust account did not appear until after the investigation had begun into Doctor Aâ€™s complaint.Â  ODC also noted that respondentâ€™s assurances that he was still in compliance with the DDA prevented investigation of Matter A until 2004.Â  Furthermore, ODC contends that much of the delay was due to respondentâ€™s failure to supply adequate financial records and ODCâ€™s difficulty in reconstructing trust account transactions.Â  ODC acknowledges the delay in obtaining the transcript of the hearing and in drafting the sub-panel report but maintains such delay is not attributable to either party.
We agree with ODC that the substantial delay in the proceedings is not attributable to respondent or to ODC.Â  We do not consider the delay to be an aggravating or a mitigating circumstance.
CONCLUSION
ODC objects to the Panelâ€™s recommendation of a thirty day suspension.Â  Citing past cases, ODC seeks a harsher sanction for respondentâ€™s misconduct.Â  We are not bound by the Panelâ€™s recommendation but rather administer the sanction we deem appropriate after a thorough review of the record.Â  In re Strickland, 354 S.C. 169, 580 S.E.2d 126 (2003).Â  
 
Although we are aware of respondentâ€™s good reputation and positive achievements, we cannot overlook the serious violations that have occurred.Â  Accordingly, we adopt all sanctions recommended by the Panel and increase respondentâ€™s suspension from the practice of law to six months.Â  Within sixty (60) days of the filing of this opinion, respondent shall pay costs associated with this proceeding in the amount of $2645.11.Â  Within fifteen (15) days of the filing of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] We agree with ODC that the pre-2000 version of Rule 403 that was in effect prior to the DDA and prior to the appearances that are at issue in this action is not relevant to our analysis.

title: In the Matter of James Stone Craven
description: This is a disciplinary opinion in which the Court definitely suspended an attorney.
text:
IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


	
		
			
				In the Matter of James Stone Craven, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26341
Submitted May 14, 2007 - Filed June 11, 2007Â Â Â  

DEFINITE SUSPENSION


	
		
			
				Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
				
				James Stone Craven, of Greenville, pro
				se.Â  
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of a definite suspension from the practice of law of not less than six (6) months or more than two (2) years.Â  Respondent requests the suspension be made retroactive to the date of his interim suspension.Â  We accept the Agreement and impose a two year suspension from the practice of law.Â  The suspension shall not be made retroactive to the date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension. Â See In the Matter of Craven, 371 S.C. 393, 639 S.E.2d 150 (2006).Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as follows.Â  
 
FACTS
Respondent was admitted to the South Carolina Bar in 2001.Â  His practice primarily involved trademark and copyright law.Â 
 
Respondent asserts that he began using cocaine in an attempt to deal with the death of a loved one and other personal problems.Â  Respondentâ€™s use of cocaine increased until it became a severely debilitating condition which contributed to his divorce, the dissolution of his law firm, the eviction from his law office building, the inability to properly represent his clients, and a virtual abandonment of his law practice for a short period of time.Â  Respondent now recognizes that, at least for a short period of time during the later stages of his addiction, he was unable to provide competent, diligent representation to several of his clients and he did not adequately communicate with some of his clients about matters he had undertaken to handle for them.Â 
 
Respondent sought help from Lawyers Helping Lawyers and voluntarily entered a detoxification facility.Â  The director of Lawyers Helping Lawyers advises that respondent has been fully compliant with his recommendations, appears to be free from the use of cocaine, and that he expects respondent to abstain from the use of cocaine indefinitely.Â 
 
During the period of his addiction, respondent made numerous deposits to and withdrawals from his trust account which should have been deposited into and drawn out of his operating account.Â  On numerous occasions respondent negotiated checks on his trust account which should have been negotiated out of his operating account or his personal bank account.Â  These checks included, but are not necessarily limited to, a refund of a retainer to a client which respondent had already expended as an earned fee, payment to a restaurant for a meal, payment of a credit card statement, payments directly to himself, and five checks payable to a liquor store for cash.Â  On several occasions in March 2006, there were overdrafts and/or negative balances in respondentâ€™s trust account.Â Â  Â Â 
Respondent did not reconcile his trust account in accordance with the requirements of Rule 417, SCACR.Â  He did not maintain ledger records so as to be able to readily determine the amount held in the trust account for each client and did not keep other records required by the rule.[1] Â Â Â 
Respondent received $275 for filing fees from a client related to a trademark application.Â  Respondent represents he completed the initial portion of the work for the client but should have been holding the sum for other filing fees for additional work that was contemplated between respondent and the client.Â  When respondentâ€™s trust account obtained a negative balance as a result of checks written on the account for respondentâ€™s personal purposes, respondent effectively used the $275 for purposes other than intended.Â  Respondent represents he has subsequently repaid this client.Â  
 
Respondent represents that, with the exception of the $275, the money spent from the trust account actually belonged to himself.Â  Â However, he agrees that in withdrawing the funds in the manner stated, respondent could not readily identify the source of the monies withdrawn.Â  Respondent acknowledges it constituted misconduct to use the $275 for purposes other than intended, to commingle his personal monies with the monies of others in his trust account, to use his trust account as a personal checking account, to write checks to himself and/or for cash, and to fail to comply with the recordkeeping and money handling provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct and Rule 417, SCACR.Â  
 
On at least one occasion after being placed on interim suspension, respondent contacted a client, gave the client a closed file to demonstrate he had in fact completed his legal services to that client prior to his suspension and to support his request to the client for the payment of a $500 fee (computed by respondent to be the balance due for an earned fee on the matter).Â  Respondent now recognizes that, once placed on interim suspension, his client files and earned fees became the responsibility of the attorney appointed by the Court to protect the interests of respondentâ€™s clients.Â  See Rule 31, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
 
In accordance with the terms of the Agreement, respondent agreed as follows:Â  1) to make arrangements for random drug tests by Lab Corp (or some other facility the parties would agree upon in writing) [2] no less frequently than every 90 days;[3] 2) to continue to submit to random drug testing during the period of suspension imposed by the Court and, should he be reinstated to the practice of law, for a period of one year after his reinstatement; 3) to pay all costs associated with the drug tests when due; and 4) to cause all test reports to be sent directly from the testing facility to ODC, if the drug testing facility will do so and, if not, to forward the original of all reports within fifteen (15) days of receipt of the reports by respondent.Â 
 
In addition, respondent agreed that his failure to strictly comply with the testing provisions in the Agreement or the indication of the use of illegal drugs in any report shall be grounds for additional disciplinary proceedings.Â  Further, respondent agreed that, if he is reinstated to the practice of law and, thereafter, fails to strictly comply with the testing provisions in the Agreement or should any report indicate the use of illegal drugs, he would be subject to interim suspension from the practice of law upon presentment of any report, copies thereof, or an affidavit of lack of receipt of the reports by ODC as required by the Agreement.Â 
 
Respondent and ODC stipulated and agreed that the drug testing reports or copies thereof shall be presumed admissible in any and all proceeding before the Commission on Lawyer Conduct, the Committee on Character and Fitness, and the Court without the necessity of ODC having such reports identified and/or authenticated by any personnel of the testing facility.Â  While respondent shall be entitled to challenge any test results he deems inaccurate, the reported results shall be presumed accurate and the burden of proof shall be on respondent to demonstrate the inaccuracy of any report by the clear and convincing standard.Â 
 
Finally, prior to filing a Petition for Reinstatement, respondent agrees to pay $182 to the court reporter who transcribed his on-the-record, under oath interview.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 
Respondent has no prior disciplinary history.Â  To the best knowledge and belief of ODC, respondent has fully cooperated with inquiries into this matter, including voluntarily submitting to an on-the-record, under oath interview, waiving the formalities of time and notice and doing so without requiring prior notice of matters to be addressed in the interview. The director of Lawyers Helping Lawyers advises respondent continues to work closely with the program and to follow his recommendations.Â  Respondent recognizes that the use of or addiction to mind altering substances is not a defense to disciplinary proceedings and offers information related thereto only as an admission of that misconduct and in mitigation of other misconduct.Â 
 
LAW
Respondent admits that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under Rule 413, RLDE, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding professional conduct of lawyers), Rule 7(a)(5) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to engage in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring the courts or the legal profession into disrepute or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice law), Rule 7(a)(6) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate the oath of office), and Rule 7(a)(7) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to willfully violate a valid court order issued by a court of this state).Â  In addition, respondent admits he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR: 
Â Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to a client); Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing a client); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep client reasonably informed about status of a matter and promptly comply with reasonable requests for information); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall safekeep client Â property); Rule 8.4(a) (lawyer shall not violate the Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(b) (lawyer shall not commit a criminal act that reflects adversely on the lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness, or fitness as a lawyer in other respects); and Rule 8.4(c) (it shall be professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct involving moral turpitude).Â  Further, respondent admits he has violated the financial recordkeeping provisions of Rule 417, SCACR.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and impose a two year definite suspension from the practice of law.Â  Respondentâ€™s request that the suspension be applied retroactively to the date of his interim suspension is denied.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â Â Â Â Â Â 
 
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.Â  WALLER, J., not participating.

[1] Respondent represents that, due to the nature of his practice, there were rarely any large sums of money in his trust account.Â  ODC has no basis to dispute this representation.Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
 
[2] The random drug tests shall be for standard reportable percentages of cocaine, marijuana, opiates, and other common illegal drugs routinely included in such a test.Â  
 
[3] Respondent agreed to make the arrangements with a drug testing facility within fifteen (15) days of the date of the Agreement.Â

title: State v. Gillian
description: This criminal case involves the issues of whether the Court of Appeals erred by upholding the trial court's decision to (1) admit evidence of two prior burglaries committed by petitioner and (2) not to admit evidence of a police ruse designed to coerce petitioner into confessing.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Steve Gillian, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Richland County
Â Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26342
Heard April 4, 2007 - Filed June 11, 2007Â  
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for petitioner.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,
				Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Brown, of Columbia, and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Petitioner was convicted of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment without parole.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed.Â  State v. Gillian, 360 S.C. 433, 602 S.E.2d 62 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  We now affirm as modified.
FACTS
The body of the victim, Jason Ward, was found about 8:30 a.m. on January 28, 2001, behind the Boozer Shopping Center.Â  Richland County police investigated Wardâ€™s death initially by tracing his activities in the days leading up to his death.Â  The police determined Ward was with petitioner from approximately midnight on January 28 until his death.
Around midnight, petitioner, Jeremiah Page, and several friends, most of whom had been drinking, met at Michael Glennâ€™s home.  Shortly after arriving at Glennâ€™s home, petitioner left and brought Ward back to the party.  Subsequently, petitioner and Ward left the party and drove to the apartment of one of Wardâ€™s co-workers.
After petitioner and Ward left the party, Page acted violently and was forcefully removed from the house.  Once he calmed down outside, Page asked if he could reenter the residence and use the phone to secure a ride home.  Once inside, Page telephoned petitioner and informed him of the previous altercation.  Petitioner and Ward returned to the party at the Glenn residence approximately ten minutes after petitioner spoke with Page.
Upon arriving at the Glenn residence, petitioner physically attacked at least four people, including breaking one personâ€™s nose by head-butting him.Â  Petitioner demanded to see the two men who had thrown Page out of Glennâ€™s house.  He asked the men why they attacked Page and threatened to beat them up for attacking Page.  After questioning them, petitioner turned his anger upon Page for misleading him.Â  Petitioner beat Page, who was crying and trying to cover his face.
At this point, Ward, who had been sitting quietly at the kitchen table, confronted petitioner about his behavior.  A guest at the party testified Ward stated: Â â€œWhy are you messing with these kids, man? Â They are scared of you.  They donâ€™t want to fight you.â€  Petitioner then directed his anger toward Ward, who calmly refused to fight petitioner despite several minutes of attempted instigation and taunting.  Ward eventually responded to petitionerâ€™s threats by quickly punching him a few times and pinning him to the floor.  After petitioner agreed to calm down, Ward allowed him to stand up, but the threats continued.
Around 5:30 a.m., Ward agreed to leave the party with petitioner, despite another party guest warning Ward not to leave with petitioner.Â  Before leaving, petitioner stated, â€œYou will see this in the newspaper tomorrow.â€
Around 6:30 a.m., residents of an area close to the Boozer Shopping Center heard gunshots.Â  Wardâ€™s body was later found behind the shopping center, with four bullet wounds to the head and one to the neck.Â  The wounds were caused by .38 caliber copper-jacketed bullets.Â  Markings on the recovered bullets were consistent with bullets fired from a .38 caliber handgun manufactured by the Taurus Company, as well as seven other manufacturers.Â  The murder weapon was never recovered.
Petitioner arrived at his parentsâ€™ home around 8:30 a.m. on Sunday morning and entered his brotherâ€™s bedroom.Â  Petitioner confessed to his brother that he had shot Ward several times and that he did not feel remorse.Â  He told his brother to watch the news because the murder would be on the news.
Around 9:00 a.m., petitioner walked over to his cousinâ€™s house.Â  The cousin testified petitioner, who was drunk, told him he had gone to a party and beat up several people.Â  Petitioner also told him he killed someone, explaining that he lured the victim behind the jewelry store he had once robbed under the guise of showing the victim how he broke into the store.Â  He told his cousin he might see it in the newspaper.
Dems Jewelry Store, in the Boozer Shopping Center, reported a break-in and a resulting loss of 34 womenâ€™s Tag Heuer watches in July of 2000.Â  Steven Livingston, the owner and manager of the jewelry store, testified as to the details of the break-in.Â  Page and petitionerâ€™s cousin stated that petitioner had previously told them that he had robbed a jewelry store and had taken several watches.Â  Another witness, Dustin Johnson, testified that upon petitionerâ€™s directions he had pawned twelve Tag Heuer watches.
The weapon that killed Ward was never found.Â  However, in investigating petitionerâ€™s connection to Wardâ€™s death, officers linked petitioner and five men to a residential burglary in Lexington County.Â  All five of the men testified at trial as to the details of the burglary, and the testimonies of all five men were essentially in accordance with one another.Â  The solicitor also presented testimony from Kevin Collins, the detective with the Lexington County Sheriffâ€™s Department who investigated the robbery, and from the resident, Ronnie Muller.Â  The purpose of the testimony was to place the alleged murder weapon in the hands of petitioner around the time of the murder.
Testimony revealed petitioner planned the burglary which took place on January 26, 2001.Â  Petitioner obtained a map of the inside of the home and copied keys that allowed entry to the home.[1]Â  Petitioner recruited the five men to actually enter the house for him.Â  While the five men entered the home, petitioner waited at a nearby gas station.Â  A five shot Taurus .38 caliber revolver was one of the items taken from the home.
The men met petitioner following the burglary.Â  Petitioner was furious at the groupâ€™s failure to steal any items of value.Â  However, Page testified petitioner was enthusiastic about the theft of the gun, which he placed in his car, stating he intended to use it to â€œdo some dirt.â€Â  One participant, Jessie Boot, testified the gun was a black revolver with a brown handle.Â  Another participant, David Grice, testified the gun was a brown-handled, black metal .38 that said Taurus on it.Â  Petitioner, along with a few of the men, then returned to the home to steal additional items, some of which were taken to a wooded area near petitionerâ€™s parentsâ€™ home.Â  Several of the men testified they saw petitioner place the gun in a brown paper bag and place it inside his car.
 
The following day, petitioner contacted an associate in the music industry to purchase bullets for the gun, but the man refused.Â  Thereafter, Dustin Johnson reluctantly agreed to purchase the bullets from a local Wal-Mart.Â  Both Johnson and petitioner were identified on store security video purchasing the bullets on January 27.
Prior to the start of the trial, defense counsel moved to have evidence of the two burglaries excluded under Rules 403 and 404(b), SCRE, and under State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923).Â  The trial judge ruled evidence of the burglaries was admissible.Â  Before the residential burglary testimony began, the trial judge issued a limiting instruction to the jury that they could consider the evidence for intent and identity, but not as a comment on petitionerâ€™s character.Â  At the close of the Stateâ€™s evidence, defense counselâ€™s motion for a mistrial based on the prior bad act evidence regarding the residential burglary was denied.
ISSUES

	
		
			I. 
			Did the Court of Appeals err by 
			upholding the trial courtâ€™s decision to admit evidence of two prior 
			burglaries committed by petitioner?
 
		
		
			II.  
			
			Did the Court of Appeals err by 
			upholding the trial courtâ€™s decision not to admit evidence of a 
			police ruse designed to coerce petitioner into confessing?
		
	

DISCUSSION
I. Evidence of Prior Burglaries
Regarding both burglaries, the Court of Appeals held that evidence of the Dems jewelry store burglary and the residential burglary was admissible under the res gestae theory.
We find the Court of Appeals erred because neither burglary furnishes part of the context of the crime nor are they necessary for a full presentation of the case.Â  See State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 470 S.E.2d 366 (1996) (one of the accepted bases for the admissibility of evidence of other crimes arises when such evidence furnishes part of the context of the crime or is necessary to a full presentation of the case).Â  Neither burglary is needed to complete the story of the crime of murder.Â  See id. (evidence of other crimes is admissible where that evidence is needed to complete the story of the crime on trial by proving its immediate context or the res gestae).Â  Accordingly, the Court of Appeals erred by finding the evidence of both burglaries was admissible as part of the res gestae of Wardâ€™s murder.Â  See, e.g., State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 536 S.E.2d 679 (2000) (evidence of an escortâ€™s assault and robbery is not admissible as part of the res gestae of the murder of another escort because the murder occurred nearly two days after the assault and robbery; further, the crimes were not so intertwined that one cannot be proven without mention of the other).
The Court of Appeals also found the State presented clear and convincing evidence that petitioner committed the burglaries.Â  The Court of Appeals further found the evidence was admissible as tending to establish petitionerâ€™s identity as Wardâ€™s murderer pursuant to Rule 404(b), SCRE.
Evidence of other crimes is not admissible to prove the character of a person in order to show action in conformity therewith.Â  Rule 404(b), SCRE.Â  The evidence may, however, be admissible to show identity.Â  Id.Â  If the defendant was not convicted of the prior crime, evidence of the prior bad act must be clear and convincing.Â  State v. Pagan, 369 S.C. 201, 631 S.E.2d 262 (2006).
A. Evidence of Dems jewelry store burglary
The Dems burglary evidence is clear and convincing and falls into the identity exception.Â  The evidence served to show the identity of the murderer given petitionerâ€™s confession to his cousin that he lured the victim behind the jewelry store he had once robbed and given that Wardâ€™s body was found in the vicinity of the Dems store. Â Consequently, evidence regarding the Dems burglary was relevant and probative on the issue of identity.Â  See, e.g., State v. Bell, 302 S.C. 18, 393 S.E.2d 364 (1990) (by his own actions, Bell linked the two murders together and consequently the evidence of the taped telephone conversations between Bell and the victimâ€™s family was probative of his conduct).Â  
 
Although the evidence is admissible to show identity, it must also be determined whether the probative value of the evidence is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice.Â  See Rule 403, SCRE (although relevant, evidence may be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice). Â The determination of the prejudicial effect of the evidence must be based on the entire record and the result will generally turn on the facts of each case. Â State v. Bell, 302 S.C. 18, 393 S.E.2d 364, cert. denied, 498 U.S. 881 (1990).
The amount of evidence regarding the specifics of the Dems burglary was unnecessary.Â  We find, however, that the admission of the evidence was harmless given that petitionerâ€™s guilt has been proven by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached.Â  See State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 377 S.E.2d 581 (1989) (insubstantial error not affecting the result of the trial is harmless where guilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached); see also State v. Sherard, 303 S.C. 172, 399 S.E.2d 595 (1991) (appellate courts will generally not set aside convictions due to insubstantial errors not affecting the result).
Other competent evidence established petitionerâ€™s guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  There was ample testimony regarding petitionerâ€™s altercation with Ward and his veiled threat towards Ward only hours before the murder.Â  The evidence also showed that petitioner was the last one seen with Ward immediately prior to the murder and that he confessed the murder to his brother and cousin.Â  Therefore, although the quantity of testimony about the Dems burglary was inappropriate, any error in allowing the evidence was harmless.
B. Evidence of the residential burglary
Evidence that petitioner was involved in the residential burglary was clear and convincing.Â  Several witnesses were able to testify to his involvement.Â  Further, petitioner conceded the evidence was clear and convincing.
The burglary evidence was presented in an effort to show the identity of the perpetrator by showing that petitioner was in possession of a stolen gun that was consistent with the type of weapon used to kill the victim.Â  The evidence showed petitioner placed the stolen .38 caliber Taurus five-shot revolver in his car and later purchased .38 caliber bullets.Â  Other evidence showed that the victim had been shot five times and that the recovered bullets were consistent with those fired by a Taurus revolver.Â  Accordingly, the evidence was properly admissible to show identity.Â  See State v. Southerland, 316 S.C. 377, 447 S.E.2d 862 (1994)[2] (evidence that Southerland stole the shotgun used to kill the victim from a trailer two weeks before the murder and that he traded the shotgun for drugs the day after the murder was admissible to prove identity).
However, even if prior bad act evidence is clear and convincing and falls within an exception, it must be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice to the defendant.Â  State v. Pagan, supra.Â  Proving the identity of petitioner as the perpetrator was an important issue in the trial.Â  Allowing the State to present evidence of the burglary in an effort to show the alleged murder weapon was in petitionerâ€™s hands immediately prior to the murder was highly probative.
We find, however, that the trial court should have limited the quantity of the evidence presented about the burglary.Â  Not all of the evidence was necessary.Â  For example, one of the Stateâ€™s witnesses, Dustin Johnson, testified about the burglary but did not testify that he saw a gun stolen from the house or that petitioner had the gun around the time of the burglary.Â  Another witness, Brandon Cannon, did not give a description of the gun.Â  Accordingly, the State did not need Cannonâ€™s or Johnsonâ€™s testimony about the burglary in their effort to show petitioner was in possession of the type of gun that was used in the murder.
Further, there was an extensive amount of evidence presented about the burglary that was unrelated to the gun; for instance:Â  what other items were stolen, where other stolen items were discarded, the fact petitioner led the others in committing the burglary, and the fact petitioner ransacked the house after learning the others did not find money on their first visit.Â  Considering the volume of the testimony about the residential burglary, petitioner was prejudiced by the admission of that amount of extraneous testimony.
However, we conclude the admission of the extraneous evidence was harmless given that petitionerâ€™s guilt has been proven by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached.Â  See State v. Bailey, supra.Â  Although the trial court erroneously allowed the State to provide extraneous testimony about the burglary, other competent evidence, as previously discussed, established petitionerâ€™s guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  Therefore, the courtâ€™s error in allowing the extraneous burglary evidence was harmless.Â  See State v. Bailey, supra; State v. Sherard, supra.
II. Evidence of the police ruse
At trial, defense counsel was not allowed to elicit testimony from Lieutenant Smith about a ruse the police used in an attempt to convince petitioner to confess to the crime.Â  In testimony proffered outside the juryâ€™s presence, Smith admitted police falsified aerial photographs to show petitionerâ€™s vehicle at the rear of the Boozer Shopping Center around the time of the shooting.Â  The ruse was used in an interview with petitioner to obtain a confession; however, petitioner did not confess.
Defense counsel also attempted to show during the proffered testimony that Smith omitted details of the ruse from his report on the investigation.Â  Defense counsel argued this information should have been presented to the jury both to show the lack of confidence the police had in their case and the possible lack of integrity in the investigation based on lack of documentation of the ruse.Â  The trial judge ruled evidence of the ruse was not relevant because there was no other indication the State had manufactured other evidence or done anything else improper.Â  The judge further ruled that the admission of the evidence would confuse the jury because there were no â€œfruitsâ€ obtained from the ruse.Â  The Court of Appeals found the trial judge did not err by refusing to admit the evidence.
Evidence is relevant if it tends to make more or less probable a fact in issue.Â  Rule 401, SCRE; State v. Huggins, 336 S.C. 200, 519 S.E.2d 574 (1999).[3]Â  Although relevant, evidence may be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury.Â  Rule 403, SCRE.Â  The relevancy of evidence is an issue within the trial judgeâ€™s discretion.Â  State v. Huggins, supra.
There is no abuse of discretion here.Â  Evidence that the ruse failed to elicit a confession is not relevant to the circumstances of Wardâ€™s death.Â  It is also not relevant because there is no suggestion by petitioner that the State manufactured any evidence or engaged in any other improprieties in investigating the case.Â  Therefore, the Court of Appeals correctly ruled that the trial judge properly excluded the evidence.
Petitioner argues that, pursuant to Frazier v. Cupp, 394 U.S. 731 (1969), and State v. Von Dohlen, 322 S.C. 234, 471 S.E.2d 689, cert. denied, 519 U.S. 972 (1996), evidence of the ruse should have been admitted so that the jury could have considered how it reflected on the strength of the Stateâ€™s case.Â  The Court of Appeals properly found that these cases are inapplicable because they involve determining whether a confession was voluntarily given after examining all the circumstances surrounding the confession.Â  Here, there is no confession and no statements for the jury to determine how they were given and if they were voluntary.
Accordingly, the trial judge properly excluded testimony regarding the ruse.Â  See State v. Douglas, 369 S.C. 424, 632 S.E.2d 845 (2006) (the admission or exclusion of evidence is a matter addressed to the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion and its ruling will not be disturbed in the absence of a manifest abuse of discretion accompanied by probable prejudice).
CONCLUSION
We find the Court of Appeals erred by holding evidence of the burglaries was admissible as res gestae evidence.Â  Regarding both burglaries, we find the evidence was probative to the issue of identity; however, the amount of evidence should have been limited by the trial judge.Â  Given the overwhelming evidence of guilt, however, the admission of the extraneous evidence regarding the burglaries was harmless error.Â  We further hold the trial judge properly excluded testimony regarding the ruse the police used in an effort to obtain petitionerâ€™s confession.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the Court of Appeals is
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]There is a Walmart video showing petitioner and Page having the keys copied.
[2]Cert. denied, 513 U.S. 1166 (1995).
[3]Cert. denied, 528 U.S. 1172 (2000).

title: State v. Sweet
description: A jury found Appellant guilty for offenses related to the distribution and possession of crack cocaine within the proximity of a school.  On appeal, Appellant alleges that the trial court erred in admitting evidence with a defective chain of custody.  We reverse Appellantâ€™s distribution convictions and remand.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Tony T-juan Sweet, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26344
Heard April 18, 2007 - Filed June 11, 2007Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Deputy
          Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General
          Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia, and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of
          Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â Â Â Â  A jury found Tony T-Juan
  Sweet (â€œAppellantâ€) guilty for offenses related to the distribution and
  possession of crack cocaine within the proximity of a school.Â  On appeal,
  Appellant alleges that the trial court erred in admitting evidence with a defective
  chain of custody, and commenting on the facts of the case in the presence of
the jury.Â  We reverse Appellantâ€™s distribution convictions and remand.
Factual/Procedural Background
In
  June 2003, the Greenville police department arranged for a confidential
  informant to purchase drugs from Appellant at a local motel.Â  Police officers
  searched the informant and his car for drugs before following him to the motel
  where the officers maintained video surveillance of the motel parking lot.Â  The
  officers also wired the informant so that the transaction could be monitored.Â 
  Officers watched as the informant met Appellant outside the motel and then
  accompanied Appellant inside a motel room.Â  Although they did not visually
  witness what occurred inside the motel room, the officers testified to hearing
  only the informantâ€™s and one other voice through the informantâ€™s wire.Â 
  Likewise, video surveillance did not observe anyone entering or exiting the
  motel room during that time.
When
  the confidential informant left the motel, officers followed him back to the
  police station where he handed over 0.21 grams of crack cocaine from the
  apparent drug purchase.Â  Meanwhile, back at the motel, waiting officers
  arrested Appellant when he exited the room and attempted to leave on his
  bicycle.Â  Upon searching Appellant, officers found a plastic bag containing
  4.27 grams of crack cocaine.Â  
At
  trial, the State sought to admit both the drugs received from the informant and
  the drugs seized in the search of Appellant.Â  Appellant objected to the
  introduction of the evidence, arguing that since the informant was unavailable
  to testify at trial, the State had not established a proper chain of custody.Â 
  The trial court overruled Appellantâ€™s objection, stating that the evidence
  showing the drugs came from Appellant was â€œcircumstantial . . . [a]t a minimal.[1]â€Â 
  The court denied Appellantâ€™s subsequent motion for a mistrial based on this
  remark.
A
  jury convicted Appellant of distribution of crack cocaine, distribution of
  crack cocaine within the proximity of a school,[2] possession of crack cocaine with intent to distribute, and possession of crack
  cocaine with intent to distribute with in the proximity of a school.Â  The trial
  court sentenced Appellant to consecutive sentences of fifteen years and five
  years for the distribution charges, and concurrent sentences of fifteen years
  and ten years on the possession charges.Â Â This appeal followed.
This
  case was certified to this Court from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule
  204(b), SCACR.Â  Appellant raises the following issues for review:

  
    I. 
    
    Did the trial court err in
  admitting drug evidence obtained from the informant because the chain of
  custody was defective?  
  
    
  
  
    II.  
    Did the trial court err in failing
  to direct a mistrial after commenting in the presence of the jury that the
  State had established by “circumstantial evidence at a minimum” that Appellant
  sold the drugs being offered into evidence?
  

Standard of Review
Decisions
  regarding the admissibility of evidence and whether to grant or deny a mistrial
  are within the discretion of the trial court and will not be reversed on appeal
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Pagan, 369 S.C. 201, 208, 631
  S.E.2d 262, 265 (2006); State v. Stanley, 365 S.C. 24, 33, 615 S.E.2d
  455, 460 (2005).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the conclusions of the
  trial court either lack evidentiary support or are controlled by an error of
  law.Â  Pagan, 369 S.C. at 208, 631 S.E.2d at 265.
Law/Analysis 
I.    Chain of custody
Appellant
  argues that the trial court erred in admitting evidence of drugs purchased by
  an unknown confidential informant because the chain of custody was defective.Â  We
  agree.
As a
  preliminary matter, the State argues that this issue is not preserved for
  appeal because Appellant did not renew his objection to this evidence at the
  time the evidence was introduced.Â  To properly preserve an issue for review there
  must be a contemporaneous
  objection that is ruled upon by the trial courtÂ  State v.
    Johnson, 363 S.C. 53, 58, 609 S.E.2d 520, 523 (2005).Â  
In
  this case, the State sought to admit two pieces of drug evidence at trial:Â  the
  drugs that the informant allegedly purchased from Appellant and turned over to
  the police upon arriving back at the station (Stateâ€™s Exhibit No. 2); and the
  drugs which police seized from Appellant incident to his arrest in the motel parking
  lot (Stateâ€™s Exhibit No. 1).Â  The Stateâ€™s first attempt to admit drug evidence
  came during the testimony of the officer who received the drugs from the
  informant back at the police station.Â  When the State moved to admit these
  drugs, i.e., Stateâ€™s Exhibit No. 2, defense counsel objected on the grounds
  that the State had not revealed an adequate chain of custody to satisfy
  admissibility requirements.Â  Based on the defective chain of custody, the trial
  court declined to admit the drugs at that time.Â  
Later
  in the trial, the State attempted to simultaneously admit both Stateâ€™s Exhibit
  No. 1 (the drugs found on Appellant after his arrest) and Stateâ€™s Exhibit No. 2
  (the drugs received from the confidential informant) during the testimony of the
  forensic chemist.Â  At this point, defense counsel objected to the admissibility
  of Stateâ€™s Exhibit No. 1 on the grounds that the State failed to establish an
  adequate chain of custody.Â  Specifically, defense counsel stated, â€œ[T]here is
  no evidence that this is attributed to the defendant or came in from any
  source.Â  The officer claims, you know, he got it from somewhere.Â  And that
  thereâ€™s no connection between the defendant and this substance.â€Â  The State now
  argues that defense counselâ€™s failure to specifically object to Stateâ€™s Exhibit
  No. 2 prevents Appellant from raising the issue to this Court.
We
  find that Appellantâ€™s failure to renew his objection to Stateâ€™s Exhibit No. 2
  does not amount to a failure to preserve the issue.Â  The grounds for defense
  counselâ€™s objection to Stateâ€™s Exhibit No. 1 clearly refer to the absence of
  testimony from the informant with respect to Stateâ€™s Exhibit No. 2, the drugs
  received from the informant.Â  Conversely, the drugs marked as Stateâ€™s Exhibit
  No. 1 were retrieved directly from Appellantâ€™s front pocket incident to arrest
  and an objection to their admissibility based on a gap in the chain of custody would
  have been nonsensical.Â  Because Appellantâ€™s objection clearly refers to the
  drugs received from the confidential informant, Appellant should not be
  penalized for an apparent misstatement in referring to the exhibit number of
  the objectionable evidence.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76,
  497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œ[A]n objection must be sufficiently specific to
  inform the trial court of the point being urged by the objector.â€).Â  Therefore,
  we find that the issue has been properly preserved for appeal.
Turning
  to the merits, this Court has long held that a party offering into evidence
  fungible items such as drugs or blood samples must establish a complete chain
  of custody as far as practicable.Â  Benton v. Pellum, 232 S.C. 26,
  33, 100 S.E.2d 534, 537 (1957).Â  Where an analyzed substance that has passed
  through several hands, the identity of individuals who acquired the evidence
  and what was done with the evidence between the taking and the analysis must
  not be left to conjecture.Â  Id. at 33-34, 100 S.E.2d at 537.Â 
  Accordingly, if the identity of each person handling the evidence is
  established, and the manner of handling is reasonably demonstrated, no abuse of
  discretion by the trial court is shown in admitting the evidence absent proof
  of tampering, bad faith, or ill-motive.Â  State v. Taylor, 360 S.C. 18,
  25, 598 S.E.2d 735, 738 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
Testimony
  from each custodian of fungible evidence, however, is not a prerequisite to
  establishing a chain of custody sufficient for admissibility.Â  Id. at 27, 598 S.E.2d at 739. Â Where other evidence establishes the
  identity of those who have handled the evidence and reasonably demonstrates the
  manner of handling of the evidence, our courts have been willing to fill gaps
  in the chain of custody due to an absent witness.Â  See State v. Williams, 297 S.C. 290, 376 S.E.2d 773 (1989) (upholding the admissibility
  of a blood test even though a nurse who drew the blood from the defendant did
  not testify at trial; hospital forms completed by the absent nurse and
  testimony from the other evidence custodians sufficiently established a chain
  of custody).
In
  the instant case, we find that without the testimony of the confidential
  informant, the Stateâ€™s proof fails to establish a complete chain of custody.Â  None
  of the chain of custody witnesses testified to seeing inside the motel room in
  order to establish who was in the room making the alleged transaction.Â  Additionally,
  none of the witnesses who heard only â€œone other voiceâ€ over the informantâ€™s
  body wire could affirmatively identify this voice as being that of Appellant.Â 
  Although Greenville police officers testified to a brief search of the informant
  both before and after the incident, and that they observed no other individuals
  enter or exit the room during their surveillance, this circumstantial evidence
  does not show how the informant came into possession of the drug evidence and
  in what condition he received it.Â  See State v. Chisolm, 355 S.C.
  175, 584 S.E.2d 401 (Ct. App. 2003) (holding that the names and signatures of
  two evidence technicians on the evidence bag did not sufficiently prove chain
  of custody where the two technicians were not present at trial to testify to
  receiving the evidence).Â  Because the officersâ€™ testimony does not fill the gap
  in the chain of custody left by the unavailable informant, the trial court
  erred in admitting the drug evidence received by the confidential informant.Â  
The
  State argues that the officersâ€™ knowledge of the confidential informantâ€™s name
  establishes his identity and therefore, the issue in this case is merely a
  question of the credibility of the drug evidence rather than its admissibility.Â 
  This argument is based on the longstanding rule that proof of the chain of
  custody need not negate all possibility of tampering so long as the party
  seeking to admit the evidence has established a complete chain of custody at
  least as far as practicable.Â  Benton, 232 S.C. at 33, 100 S.E.2d at
  537.Â Â  In applying this rule, this Court has held that where a party has
  established the identity of each person in the chain of custody, issues
  regarding the care of the evidence only go to the weight of the specimen as credible
  evidence, and not its admissibility.Â  State v. Carter, 344 S.C. 419,
  424, 544 S.E.2d 835, 837 (2001).Â  
We
  find that the Stateâ€™s argument is misapplied in the instant case.Â  The rules
  upon which the State relies require the State in the first instance to have
  established a complete chain of custody at least as far a practicable.Â  As
  discussed above, in the absence of testimony from the confidential informant,
  the Stateâ€™s proof of chain of custody is incomplete because it fails to establish
  the identity of each custodian and the manner of handling of the evidence.Â  Cf.
    id. (holding that where all custodians of a blood sample testified, the
  chain of custody was complete and therefore, evidence regarding a discrepancy
  in the handling of the blood sample went to the weight of the sample as
  credible evidence and not its admissibility).Â  Furthermore, although the
  unavailability of the confidential informant made it impracticable to produce
  him as a witness at trial, the State could have taken a sworn statement from
  the informant before he left the station and produced the statement at trial
  under the procedures of Rule 6(b), SCRCrimP.[3]Â  See Chisolm, 355 S.C. at 180, 584 S.E.2d at 404 (finding drug evidence
  inadmissible where â€œit would not have been impracticable for the State to have
  called each custodian to testify or for the State to have submitted sworn
  statements from the custodians under . . . Rule 6(b), SCRCrimP.â€).Â  In other
  words, the State simply did not present proof of the chain of custody as far as
  practicable.Â  For these reasons, the informantâ€™s possession of the drug
  evidence may not be reduced to an issue of mere credibility based solely on the
  officersâ€™ knowledge of the informantâ€™s name.Â  
Although
  our courts have been willing to fill in gaps in the chain of custody where
  other evidence reasonably demonstrates the identity of each individual in the
  chain of custody and the manner of handling of the evidence, such circumstances
  are not present here.Â  Accordingly, we hold that the trial court erred in admitting
  evidence of drugs allegedly purchased from Appellant by the informant.
  
II.  Remark by the trial court
  in the presence of the jury.
Because
  our decision regarding the chain of custody is dispositive in this case, we
  decline to address Appellantâ€™s argument that the trial court erred in refusing
  to grant a mistrial based on the courtâ€™s remark that the State had established by
  â€œcircumstantial evidence at a minimumâ€ that the drugs came from Appellant.Â  See
    Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d
  591, 598 (1999) (providing that an appellate court need not address additional
  issues if the resolution of another issue is dispositive).Â  
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we
  reverse Appellantâ€™s distribution convictions and remand the case for a new
  trial on these charges.
MOORE,
  WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.
  

[1] Neither party disputes that from the context of this remark, the word â€œminimumâ€
  was the appropriate/intended usage.
[2] The drug transaction took place at a motel that was within one-half mile of Bob Jones University.
[3] Rule 6(b), SCRCrimP, allows for the admission of sworn statements to prove
  chain of custody in lieu of the appearance of a chain of custody witness.

title: City of Rock Hill v. Suchenski
description: Respondent was found guilty by the Rock Hill Municipal Court for driving with an unlawful alcohol concentration.  The circuit court reversed the conviction due to the cityâ€™s failure to comply with S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2953.  The Court affirmed the reversal, holding that the city failed to preserve the issue by not seeking a ruling from the circuit court concerning the applicability of statutory exceptions.  In addition, the Court held dismissal of the charge was a proper remedy pursuant to the statute.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The City of Rock Hill, Appellant,
        v.
        Cynthia A. Suchenski, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26345
  Heard January 4, 2007 - Filed June 18,
  2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Harry P. Collins, of Rock Hill, for Appellant.
        Thomas F. McDow, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ACTING JUSTICE
  MANNING:Â  This is an appeal from the Rock Hill municipal court.Â  Cynthia Suchenski (respondent) was found guilty of driving
  with an unlawful alcohol concentration (DUAC), and the circuit court reversed
  her conviction based on the City of Rock Hillâ€™s (Cityâ€™s) failure to comply with
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2953 (2006), which requires the arresting officer to
  provide videotaping of the incident site.Â  We affirm.
  
FACTS
Respondent
  was arrested for driving under the influence (DUI) and was later charged with
  DUAC.Â  At the incident site, the arresting officer did not videotape the entire
  arrest as required by Â§ 56-5-2953 because the officerâ€™s camera ran out of
  tape.Â  The videotaping began upon activation of the officerâ€™s blue lights and
  recorded two field sobriety tests and the Miranda warnings, but the tape
  stopped before the officer administered a third field sobriety test and before
  respondent was arrested.
At trial,
  respondent moved to dismiss the charges due to the officerâ€™s failure to provide
  a complete videotape from the incident site.Â  The officer testified that a tape
  had never ended during an arrest before and that he turned on his blue lights
  and assumed the videotape was running as usual.Â  The officer stated he did not
  know the tape was about to expire.Â  The municipal court denied the motion pursuant
  to the statute on the grounds of exigent circumstances.Â  The municipal court
  also cited State v. Huntley, 349 S.C. 1, 562 S.E.2d 472 (2002), and State
    v. Mabe, 306 S.C. 355, 412 S.E.2d 386 (1991), in support of its denial of respondentâ€™s
  motion to dismiss.
The case was tried
  before a jury, and respondent was found guilty.Â  Respondent appealed her
  conviction, and the circuit court reversed, holding that respondentâ€™s motion to
  dismiss should have been granted.Â  The circuit court distinguished Huntley and Mabe, the two cases relied upon by the municipal court in denying
  respondentâ€™s motion to dismiss.Â  However, the circuit court did not address the
  finding of the municipal court that exigent circumstances excused compliance
  with the statute and simply held that the City violated the videotaping
  statute.
ISSUE
Did
  the circuit court err in reversing respondentâ€™s conviction and dismissing the
  DUAC charge?
  
ANALYSIS
In
  criminal appeals from municipal court, the circuit court does not conduct a de
  novo review.Â Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-25-105 (Supp. 2006); State v. Landis,
  362 S.C. 97, 606 S.E.2d 503 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  In criminal cases, the appellate
  court reviews errors of law only.Â  State v. Cutter, 261 S.C. 140, 199
  S.E.2d 61 (1973).Â  Therefore, our scope of review is limited to correcting the
  circuit courtâ€™s order for errors of law.Â  
The
  City first argues that the circuit court erred by determining the City violated
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2953.Â  This issue is not preserved.
Section 56-5-2953
  commands the arresting officer to videotape the individual during a DUI
  arrest.Â  Subsection (A) of the statute outlines the requirements for
  videotaping at the incident site and at the breath test site. Subsection (B) of
  the statute provides exceptions that excuse compliance with the statute.[1]Â 
  In this case, both parties agreed that the arresting officer failed to comply
  with the requirements of subsection (A), but the municipal court denied
  respondentâ€™s motion to dismiss due to an exception in subsection (B).Â  
On appeal to the
  circuit court, the City reiterated its position that noncompliance was excused
  pursuant to Â§ 56-5-2953(B).Â  However, the circuit courtâ€™s order did not address
  or even mention the exceptions in subsection (B).Â  The circuit court simply
  concluded, â€œHere, the legislature has established a procedure that must be followed in the making of a DUI arrest.Â  Here, the procedure was not
  followed.â€Â  While the circuit court correctly applied subsection (A) of the
  statute, it omitted any mention of subsection (B) of Â§ 56-5-2953.Â  
The
  City did not seek a post-judgment ruling from the circuit court on the
  potential applicability of Â§ 56-5-2953(B).Â  This precludes our review of the
  applicability of the subsection (B) exceptions, as we may only review the
  circuit courtâ€™s order for errors of law.Â  We cannot determine error regarding
  an issue not addressed by the circuit court.Â  See Williams v.
    Williams, 329 S.C. 569, 579, 496 S.E.2d 23, 29 (Ct. App. 1998), revâ€™d on
      other grounds, 335 S.C. 386, 517 S.E.2d 689 (1999) (â€œThe circuit court has
  the authority to hear motions to alter or amend the judgment when it sits in an
  appellate capacity, and these motions are required in order to preserve issues
  for further review by the Court of Appeals or the Supreme Court in cases where
  the circuit court fails to address an issue raised by a party.â€); United
    Dominion Realty Trust, Inc. v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 307 S.C. 102, 413
  S.E.2d 866 (Ct. App. 1992) (circuit court sitting on appeal did not address an
  issue and Wal-Mart made no motion pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to have the
  court rule on the issue; thus the allegation was not preserved for further
  review by the Court of Appeals).
The City next
  contends that, per Huntley, a violation of the videotaping statute
  should not result in dismissal of a charge when there was no showing of
  prejudice to the defendant.Â  We disagree.
Under Â§ 56-5-2953, a violation of the statute, with no
  mention of prejudice, may result in dismissal of the charges.Â  The statute
  provides, â€œFailure by the arresting officer to produce the videotapes required
  by this section is not alone a ground for dismissal of any charge made
  pursuant to Section 56-5-2930, 56-5-2933, or 56-5-2945 if [exceptions
  apply]â€¦â€ (emphasis added).Â  Conversely, failure to produce videotapes would be
  a ground for dismissal if no exceptions apply.
The
  circuit court found Huntley to be inapposite, and we agree. The statute
  at issue in Huntley was the implied consent statute which required a
  simulator test before administration of a breath test.Â  That statute, S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950 (2006), is silent as to the remedy for noncompliance, whereas
  the statute in this case provides for dismissal of charges when the statute is
  inexcusably violated.
  
CONCLUSION
The
  City failed to seek a ruling in the circuit court in regards to the
  applicability of the exceptions for noncompliance found in Â§ 56-5-2953(B).Â 
  Accordingly, that issue is not properly before us.Â  Finally, dismissal of the DUAC
  charge is an appropriate remedy provided by Â§ 56-5-2953 where a violation of
  subsection (A) is not mitigated by subsection (B) exceptions.
AFFIRMED.
MOORE, ACJ, WALLER,
  J., and Acting Justice James W. Johnson, Jr., concur.Â  BURNETT, J., dissenting
  in a separate opinion.
  
BURNETT, J.:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In my opinion, the issue of
  whether the circuit erred by determining the City violated S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  56-5-2953 is preserved.
 In order to
  preserve an issue for appellate review, a party must file a motion to alter or
  amend the judgment when the party raises an issue to the lower court and the
  court fails to rule upon the issue.Â  E.g., Elam v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 602 S.E.2d 772 (2004); Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v.
    Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 526 S.E.2d 716 (2000); see also Rules 52(b) and 59(e), SCRCP.Â  However, a motion to alter or amend the judgment
  under Rule 59(e) was not necessary in this case.Â  Appellantâ€™s failure to move
  to seek a ruling from the lower court on the applicability of S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  56-5-2953(B) (2006) does not violate the long-established preservation
  requirements.Â  
Both
  parties argued the applicability of subsections (A) and (B) extensively in
  their briefs and at the hearing before the lower court.Â  The lower courtâ€™s
  determination hinged on whether subsection (B) provided an excuse for the
  violation of subsection (A).Â  The lower court determined no exception in
  subsection (B) applied.Â  Although the lower courtâ€™s order only addressed
  subsection (A), the fact that subsection (B) did not apply was implicit in the
  order and, therefore, preserved for review.Â  
A
  preservation issue did not arise when the lower court implicitly ruled in the
  negative that no exception applied, as opposed to alternatively ruling in the
  positive that an exception applied.Â  For preservation purposes, it was
  unnecessary for the lower court to rule upon an exception when no such
  exception applied.Â  Hence, despite the fact the entire opinion addressed only
  subsection (A), Appellant was free to argue on appeal an exception in
  subsection (B) applied. 
Section
  56-5-2953(B), states, in pertinent part:

  Failure
    by the arresting officer to produce the videotapes required by this section is
    not alone a ground for dismissal of any charge made pursuant to Section
    56-5-2930, 56-5-2933, or 56-5-2945 if the arresting officer submits a sworn
    affidavit certifying that the videotape equipment at the time of the arrest â€¦
    was in an inoperable condition, â€¦ or in the alternative â€¦ it was physically
    impossible to produce the videotape because the person needed emergency medical
    treatment, or exigent circumstances existed.

(emphasis added).Â  In the
  instant case, the videotape began upon activation of the officerâ€™s blue lights
  and recorded two field sobriety tests and the Miranda warnings.Â  The
  tape stopped before the officer administered a third field sobriety test and a
  â€œwalk and turnâ€ test, and before Respondent was arrested.Â  The officer
  testified he assumed the videotape was running as usual and did not know the
  tape had expired prematurely.Â  The municipal court correctly denied
  Respondentâ€™s motion to dismiss based on the â€œexigent circumstancesâ€ exception
  in subsection (B).Â  
Because
  it was unnecessary for Appellant to make a motion pursuant to Rule 59(e), the
  issue of whether subsection (B) applied is preserved for review.Â  Accordingly,
  I would reverse the lower court and reinstate the decision of the municipal
  court.Â 
  

[1] Respondent argues the applicable statutory provision
  states, â€œNothing in this section prohibits the court from considering any other
  valid reason for the failure to produce the videotape based upon the totality
  of the circumstances.â€Â
