title: Davis v. School District of Greenville County
description: This is a direct appeal in a school discipline case.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Eddie Christopher Davis, Respondent
				v.
				The School District of Greenville County, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26350
Heard April 17, 2007 - Filed June 25, 2007Â Â  
REVERSED AND VACATED


	
		
			
				C. Wade Cleveland, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				Matthew J. Kappel, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE WALLER: This is a school discipline case where the hearing officer disciplined respondent Eddie Christopher Davis by transferring him from Wade Hampton High School to an alternative school.Â  The Greenville County School Board (â€œthe Boardâ€) affirmed the transfer, but the circuit court reversed.Â  The School District of Greenville County (â€œthe Districtâ€) directly appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision.Â  We reverse and vacate.
FACTS
On August 24, 2004, respondentâ€™s teacher â€œsmelled a peculiar odorâ€ coming from the area of two students which she concluded was the smell of marijuana.Â  The assistant principal, Terry Carnes, took respondent and the other student to his office where Carnes decided the odor was coming from respondentâ€™s clothes and hands.Â  The principal, Bill Utsey, confirmed the smell of marijuana on respondentâ€™s hands and clothing.[1]Â  As a result, respondent was suspended and, pursuant to the Districtâ€™s discipline policy, expulsion proceedings were initiated.[2]
That same day, respondentâ€™s mother was sent a letter informing them of the suspension and the fact that expulsion was being recommended.Â  Prior to the hearing, another letter went out informing respondentâ€™s mother of respondentâ€™s rights, including the right to a hearing before a hearing officer, the right to be represented by counsel, and â€œall other regular rightsâ€ including the right to call and question witnesses.
The hearing was held on September 2, 2004, and respondent was represented by counsel.Â  Principal Utsey testified he smelled marijuana on respondentâ€™s clothes and hands, and therefore was required to recommend that respondent be expelled.Â  Respondent denied he had smoked marijuana the morning of August 24th but testified that he had smoked a Newport menthol cigarette before coming to school.Â  
 
Respondent also presented evidence regarding drug screening tests he took on August 31, 2004, conducted by a company called Accurate Diagnostics.Â Â  The urinalysis and hair tests for marijuana both came back negative.Â  The office manager for Accurate Diagnostics testified that marijuana stays in a userâ€™s urine anywhere from 14 to 30 days, and respondentâ€™s hair sample would have shown marijuana use from the previous three months.Â  However, in response to the hearing officerâ€™s question of â€œhow little marijuana does one have to smoke to show up on a test,â€ the witness stated that if a person â€œsmoke[d] one joint, [then] that is supposed to show upâ€¦.Â  If someone takes one puff, it is likely that it may not show up.â€
Based on the evidence that three people smelled marijuana on respondent, the hearing officer ruled the misconduct charge was supported by the evidence.Â  Respondent, however, was not expelled; instead, the hearing officer assigned respondent to the Districtâ€™s alternative program.Â  Respondent appealed to the Board which affirmed the hearing officerâ€™s decision.Â  
 
Respondent then appealed to the circuit court.Â  The circuit court ruled respondent had the right to appeal under S.C. Code section 59-63-240 and summarily reversed the Boardâ€™s decision.
ISSUE
Did the circuit court have subject matter jurisdiction to review the Boardâ€™s decision affirming respondentâ€™s transfer to the alternate program? 
 
DISCUSSION
The District argues the circuit court lacked jurisdiction to review the Boardâ€™s decision because the statute governing the transfer of a student does not provide for appeal beyond the Board.Â  Respondent, on the other hand, asserts that because expulsion proceedings were initiated, this matter is governed by the expulsion statute which specifically allows for an appeal from the Boardâ€™s decision.Â  We agree with the District and find the circuit court lacked jurisdiction to hear respondentâ€™s appeal.
In Title 59 of the S.C. Code, Chapter 63, Article 3 specifically addresses the issue of student discipline. Â Section 59-63-240 states as follows, in relevant part: 
 

	The board may expel for the remainder of the school year a pupil for any of the reasons listed in Â§ 59-63-210.[3]Â  If procedures for expulsion are initiated, the parents or legal guardian of the pupil shall be notified in writing of the time and the place of a hearing either before the board or a person or committee designated by the board.Â  At the hearing the parents or legal guardian shall have the right to legal counsel and to all other regular legal rights including the right to question all witnesses.Â  If the hearing is held by any authority other than the board of trustees, the right to appeal the decision to the board is reserved to either party.â€¦ Â The pupil may be suspended from school and all school activities 
	during the time of the expulsion procedures. Â The action of the board may be appealed to the proper court.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-63-240 (2004) (emphasis added).Â  The statutory section governing the transfer of students provides:

	The board or a designated administrator may transfer a pupil to another school 
	in lieu of suspension or expulsion but only after a conference or hearing with the parents or legal guardian. Â The parents or legal guardian may appeal a transfer made by an administrator to the board.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-63-250 (2004) (emphasis added).
In Byrd v. Irmo High School, 321 S.C. 426, 468 S.E.2d 861 (1996), this Court dealt with a similar situation.Â  There, a student had been suspended for 10 days for coming to a high school football game after drinking alcohol.Â  The student attempted to appeal the suspension to the circuit court which ruled it lacked jurisdiction over public school suspensions.Â  We upheld the finding of no subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Comparing the suspension statute[4] with the expulsion statute, we found that â€œthere exists a qualitative difference in the appellate procedures granted to students being suspended and those being expelled.â€Â  Id. at 433, 468 S.E.2d at 865.Â  Specifically, the Byrd Court stated that â€œ[b]ecause the expulsion provision expressly grants the student a right to appeal to â€˜the proper court,â€™ and no such language exists in the suspension provision, it appears that the Legislature intended that suspended students not be entitled to a right to appeal beyondâ€ the Board level.[5] Â Id. at 433-34, 468 S.E.2d at 865.
In the instant case, the section governing the transfer of a student is similar to the suspension statute at issue in Byrd:Â  it does not provide for an appeal beyond the Boardâ€™s decision.Â  See Â§ 59-63-250.Â  Therefore, consistent with the plain language of section 59-63-250 and the reasoning of Byrd, we find the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to entertain respondentâ€™s appeal.Â  
 
Respondent contends, however, that because the proceedings began as expulsion proceedings, and the procedure initially followed by the District was pursuant to the expulsion statute, see Â§ 59-63-240, he retains the full appellate rights outlined in that statutory section.Â  Respondent further maintains that because the statutory language provides that the â€œaction of the board may be appealed to the proper courtâ€ - without regard to whether the action resulted in an actual expulsion - the circuit court properly found it had the power to review the Boardâ€™s action in this case.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature.â€ Â Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000).Â  Furthermore, the â€œgoal of statutory construction is to harmonize conflicting statutes whenever possible and to prevent an interpretation that would lead to a result that is plainly absurd.â€ 
    Id. at 91, 533 S.E.2d at 584.
Section 59-63-250 expressly provides for discipline in the form of a transfer â€œin lieu of suspension or expulsion;â€ therefore, it plainly envisions the possibility that the student may be involved in expulsion proceedings prior to being transferred.Â  The statute then specifically provides for only one level of appeal.Â  Had the Legislature intended for a transferred student to have all the rights outlined in the expulsion statute, it could have provided specifically for that procedure in section 59-63-250.Â  We therefore hold the Legislature intended that when a student is merely transferred, and not expelled, the review of the decision ends with the Board.Â  See Â§ 59-63-250; Hodges v. Rainey, supra (the cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the Legislature).
Indeed, a contrary interpretation would create a significant conflict between sections 59-63-240 and 59-63-250, allowing further appellate review of a transfer if the proceedings were initiated under the expulsion statute, but not of a transfer initiated under the transfer statute.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, supra (statutes should be harmonized whenever possible to prevent an interpretation that would lead to a result that is plainly absurd); see also Aledo Indep. Sch. Dist. v. Reese, 987 S.W.2d 953, 958 (Tex. App. 1999) (where the court held that a studentâ€™s transfer to an alternative education program was not an expulsion, in part because the applicable statutes provided no district court review for alternative placements but allowed further court review for expulsions).Â  Thus, once the hearing officer rejected expulsion and imposed the sanction of transfer, the transfer statute became applicable.Â  That sectionâ€™s appellate procedure simply does not provide for appeal of the Boardâ€™s decision to the circuit court.Â  See Â§ 59-63-250.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to review the Boardâ€™s decision.[6]
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we reverse the circuit courtâ€™s decision and vacate the circuit courtâ€™s order.Â  
 
REVERSED AND VACATED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] It is undisputed that no one observed any visual signs respondent was under the influence of marijuana.Â  The only evidence of marijuana use was the odor detected on respondentâ€™s hands and clothes.
[2] The Districtâ€™s Discipline Code provides that if a high school student comes onto school property after using an illegal drug, as â€œevidenced by scent, actions or admission,â€ the result will be that the principal recommends expulsion.
[3] Section 59-63-210(A) sets forth the reasons a district board of trustees may authorize the expulsion, suspension, or transfer of a student, including â€œfor violation of written rules and promulgated regulations established by the district board.â€
[4] This section provides:

	When a pupil is suspended from a class or a school, the administrator shall notify, in writing, the parents or legal guardian of the pupil, giving the reason for such suspension and setting a time and place when the administrator shall be available for a conference with the parents or guardian. Â The conference shall be set within three days of the date of the suspension. Â After the conference the parents or legal guardian may appeal the suspension to the board of trustees or to its authorized agent.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-63-230 (2004).
[5] In Floyd v. Horry County Sch. Dist., 351 S.C. 233, 569 S.E.2d 343 (2002), we clarified Byrd and held that a student may appeal to circuit court â€œfor the sole purpose of challenging a temporary school suspension underâ€ the United States Supreme Courtâ€™s decision in Goss v. Lopez, 419 U.S. 565 (1975).Â  Floyd, 351 S.C. at 237, 569 S.E.2d at 345.Â  This Court further stated that â€œ[i]f the minimal procedural standards of Goss v. Lopez are met, the suspension shall be affirmed.â€Â  Id.  Pursuant to Goss v. Lopez, the minimal process constitutionally due a student for a suspension of ten days or less is:Â  (1) oral or written notice of the charges; (2) an explanation of the evidence; and (3) an opportunity to present his side of the story.Â  419 U.S. at 579.Â  The instant appeal does not involve respondentâ€™s initial temporary suspension.Â  We nevertheless note that minimal process standards clearly were met in this case.
[6] We decline to address the remaining issues raised on appeal. Â See Hagood v. Sommerville, 362 S.C. 191, 199, 607 S.E.2d 707, 711 (2005) (the appellate court need not address additional issues when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).

title: In the Matter of O. Doyle Martin
description: In this opinion, the Court suspends O. Doyle Martin from the practice of law in this state for six months.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter of O. Doyle Martin, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26351
Heard May 29, 2007 - FiledÂ  June 25, 2007
DEFINITE SUSPENSION


	
		
			
				Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Joseph P. Turner, Jr., Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				Keith M. Babcock, of Lewis and Babcock, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits the allegations therein constitute violations of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR, and the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, and consents to the imposition of a six month suspension pursuant to Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  Respondent requests the suspension be made retroactive to the date of his interim suspension. Â See In the Matter of Martin, 371 S.C. 33, 637 S.E.2d 560 (2006).Â  We accept the agreement and suspend respondent from the practice of law in this state for six months, retroactive to the date of his interim suspension.Â  
 
FACTS
The facts as set forth in the agreement are as follows.Â  Respondent was indicted in federal court on thirty counts of mail fraud.Â  The indictment resulted from respondentâ€™s allocation, at the direction of an officer of an insurance company for which respondent did defense work, of time and charges to several of the companyâ€™s files on which the time billed had not been spent.Â  Following indictment, respondent was placed on interim suspension.Â  See In the Matter of Martin, supra.Â  
 
However, the indictment has since been dismissed.Â  Moreover, respondent represents that all of the time he billed to the company was in fact spent by him and computed at approved rates.Â  He further represents he did not bill the company for any amounts he or his firm were not due for legal services performed for the company.Â  Respondent has consistently maintained preparation of the statements requested by the officer did not constitute misconduct because he was not charging the company for any amounts not due him or his firm by the company, and he was preparing the statements with the knowledge and at the direction of the officer.[1]Â  However, in hindsight, respondent recognizes the pro rata allocation of fees on his firmâ€™s statements to the company, although at the direction of the officer, at least gave the appearance that the officer was seeking to mislead someone or some entity to the detriment of one party or to the advantage of another.Â  Respondent states that, in the future, he will make every effort to have all of his statements accurately reflect the time and charges related to the referenced file.
LAW
Respondent admits that the above allegations constitute a violation of the strict requirements of Rule 1.5 of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR (a 
lawyer shall not charge or collect an unreasonable fee), which could be construed as a violation of Rules 8.4(d) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation) and 8.4(e), RPC (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct that is prejudicial to the administration of justice) as well.Â  Finally, respondent admits the allegation would constitute grounds for discipline under Rule 7(a)(1), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct).
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and suspend respondent from the practice of law in this state for six months, retroactive to the date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension.Â  Within fifteen (15) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30 of Rule 413, SCACR.
Prior to the submission of the agreement to this Court, respondent filed a Petition to Reconsider or Vacate and for Reinstatement in which he asked the Court to reconsider or vacate the interim suspension order and permit respondent to resume the practice of law.Â  We deny the request to reconsider or vacate the interim suspension order as moot.Â  With regard to respondentâ€™s request to be reinstated to the practice of law, he will first have to comply with the requirements of Rule 32, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â 
 
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., not participating.

[1] It is not clear why the officer wanted respondentâ€™s time and charges allocated to other files respondent handled for the company.Â  The officer was terminated by the company based on alleged payments on fictitious claims generated by an adjuster in the State of Kentucky.Â  He subsequently pled guilty in federal court to a criminal offense related to his activities, but not related to the activities of respondent nor the averments in the indictment against respondent.

title: Robert Lever v. Lighting Galleries
description: Lighting Galleries, Inc. d/b/a August Lighting and Design Center, appeals an order of the Master-in-Equity holding that a mortgage given to it by respondent, Robert Lever f/k/a Leverage Builders, Inc., should be marked satisfied.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Robert D. Lever d/b/a Leverage Builders, Inc., Respondent,
				v.
				Lighting Galleries, Inc. d/b/a Augusta Lighting and Design Center, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Robert A. Smoak, Jr., Master-In-Equity
Opinion No. 26353
Heard April 18, 2007 - Filed June 25, 2007Â Â Â  

REVERSED


	
		
			
				Weston Adams, III and Paul M. Koch, of McAngus, Goudelock & Courie, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Forrest Craig Wilkerson, Jr., of Rock Hill, and Marvin B. Poston, of Powell & Poston, of Aiken, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE WALLER:Â  Appellant, Lighting Galleries, Inc. d/b/a August Lighting and Design Center, appeals an order of the Master-in-Equity holding that a mortgage given to it by respondent, Robert Lever f/k/a Leverage Builders, Inc., should be marked satisfied. Â We reverse.[1]  
FACTS/ PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In April 1988, Leverage Builders was indebted to Lighting Galleries, Inc. in the sum of $36,256.97.Â  To secure this debt, Lever signed an agreement in which he agreed to give Lighting Galleries a fourth mortgage in a one-third undivided interest it owned in property in Aiken County.Â  The agreement provided that it was for a period of one year, and would accrue interest at the rate of 9% per annum.Â  A mortgage on the property was recorded simultaneously with the above agreement.Â Â  Thereafter, On June 14, 1988, Lever signed a Note agreeing to pay Lighting Galleries $36,256.97, to be paid per the terms of the agreement, at a rate of 9% interest, and subject to an attorneyâ€™s fee of 15% if collection became necessary.Â Â 
 
In April 1989, when Lever did not timely pay in accordance with the partiesâ€™ one-year agreement, Lighting Galleries brought suit on the note in Aiken County, resulting in an order for judgment of $36,256.97, plus interest, as well as attorneyâ€™s fees of $5437.00.Â  The judgment was entered in Lancaster County.Â  It is undisputed that despite attempts to collect the debt, Lighting Galleries was unable to collect on its judgment, which expired ten years later, in April 1999.[2]Â  It is also undisputed that Lever has not paid the debt to date. 
 
Lighting Galleries initially chose not to bring a foreclosure action on the mortgage because, in 1989 the property was worthless, having had an oil spill on it, and Lighting Galleries was only a fourth-mortgagee on a 1/3 interest in the property.Â 
 
After Lighting Galleriesâ€™ judgment lien expired, Lever filed a petition and Rule to Show Cause in the circuit court,[3] seeking a ruling that the mortgage on the property should be extinguished, and contending that Lighting Galleries, Inc. had previously elected its remedy, such that it was prohibited from thereafter pursuing a foreclosure action.[4]Â  Lever sought damages, costs and attorneys fees.Â Â  The matter was referred to the Master-in-Equity who held that the judgment obtained by Lighting Galleries on the note rendered the note and mortgage inoperative, such that the mortgage should be marked satisfied.Â  Lighting Galleries appeals.
ISSUE
Did the Master err in holding the mortgage should be marked satisfied?
DISCUSSION
The Master held that â€œat the moment [Lighting Galleries] obtained the judgment on the note against [Lever], the indebtedness was then evidence by the order for judgment and no longer by the note, which became inoperative and of no further substance.Â  Since a mortgage is merely a security interest and must be based upon a note or other written evidence of an obligation, upon the entry of the judgment the mortgage likewise became inoperative since there is no provision in law for a mortgage to secure a judgment.â€Â  This was error.
A mortgagee who has a note and a mortgage to secure a debt has the option to either bring an action on the note or to pursue a foreclosure action.Â  See Perpetual Bldg. and Loan Assâ€™n of Anderson v. Braun, 270 S.C. 338, 242 S.E.2d 407 (1978) (It is not implicit in the taking of a mortgage that the creditor is to look only to the property for satisfaction of the debt. Indeed, he may ignore the security and bring an action at law on the indebtedness, or he may proceed by foreclosure to satisfy his lien); Platt v. Carroll, 125 S.C. 493, 119 S.E. 180 (1923) (The bond is not the debt, nor is the mortgage the debt; the debt is the borrowed money; the bond and the mortgage are simply separate securities for the same debt, and the creditor may pursue either security that his interest may dictate); Hatfield v. Kennedy, 1 Bay, 501 (1793) (Wherever a man has a bond and mortgage, he may pursue both at the same time, or either of them, as he thinks proper).Â  See also Blackmon v. Patel, 302 S.C. 361, 363 396 S.E.2d 128, 130 (Ct. App. 1990) (â€œSeller had no duty to pursue foreclosure of his mortgage before suing on the note. A creditor, including mortgagees, has the option of ignoring the security and suing on the note.â€ citing Edge v. Klutts Resort Realty, Inc., 276 S.C. 389, 278 S.E.2d 783 (1981); Perpetual Bldg. & Loan Assâ€™n v. Braun, 270 S.C. 338, 242 S.E.2d 407 (1978)).

	As noted by 55 Am.Jur. 2d Mortgages Â§ 524:
	The cases are uniform in holding that until the mortgage debt is actually satisfied, the recovery of a judgment on the obligation secured by a mortgage, without the foreclosure of the mortgage, although merging the debt in the judgment, has no effect upon the mortgage or its lien, 
	does not merge it, and does not preclude its foreclosure in a subsequent suit instituted for that purpose, or the exercise of the power of sale contained in the mortgage or deed of trust.

(emphasis supplied).
Lever contends the critical distinction in this case is because the judgment which Lighting Galleries obtained more than ten years ago has expired pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-35-810 (1976), the debt is now barred and the mortgage discharged.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
 
Lever cites Buist v. Dawes, 24 S.C. Eq. (3 Rich. Eq.) 281 (1851) for the proposition that Lighting Galleries, having elected to sue on the note and obtain a judgment, is bound thereby and may not now pursue a foreclosure action.Â  Buist does not support Leverâ€™s contention.Â  Buist held:

	Wherever two rights are alternatively created, or given, either in express terms, or by construction, the party to whom they are given is entitled to only one of the two, and must elect between them; but after he has made his election he is bound, and will not be allowed to elect again, unless he can shew some equitable circumstances entitling him to retract the choice he has made.Â 
	

Buist involved a widowâ€™s acceptance of dower rights which was held to destroy her right to a distributive share of her husbandâ€™s estate.Â  Buist is inapposite to those cases which allow a creditor to pursue either an action at law on a note, or proceeding by foreclosure of a mortgage.Â  Platt v. Carroll; Perpetual Bldg. and Loan Assâ€™n of Anderson v. Braun; Hatfield v. Kennedy, 1 Bay, 501 (1793); Blackmon v. Patel, Edge v. Klutts Resort Realty, Inc.
Lever also cites Gibbes v. Holmes, 31 S.C. Eq. (10 Rich. Eq.) 484 (1859) for the following proposition:

	[T]he debt must be presumed to be satisfied from the lapse of time. If this presumption prevails, the mortgage is as completely discharged as if the debt had been satisfied by actual payment. Where the statute of limitations applies, it is presumption
	juris et de jure. Â It cannot be rebutted. Â A debtor may admit that the debt has not been paid, and in the same breath insist upon the protection and bar of the statute. But 
	a presumption of satisfaction, arising from the lapse of time may be rebutted.

(Emphasis supplied).Â  We find the facts of this case amply support the rebuttal of any presumption that the debt has been satisfied; Lever concedes that he has not paid the debt.Â  
 
Moreover, in Nichols v. Briggs, 18 S.C. 473 (1883), the Court held that the above-cited language in Gibbes was mere obiter dictum.Â  The question before the Nichols Court, as stated therein, was as follows: â€œAssuming that recovery on the note considered by itself could not be had on account of the statute of limitations, must the mortgage of real property, given to secure the same debt, also be considered as barred?â€Â  The Court went on to hold that â€œThe note given is only evidence of the debt and one of the means of collecting it, and if there is a mortgage, that is only another security for the same debt. . . . A mortgage being given as a security for a debt, the general rule is that no mere change in the mode or time of payment, nothing short of an actual payment of the debt or an express release, will operate as a discharge of the mortgage. The lien lasts as long as the debt. Â 1 Hill. Mort., Â§ 3. The mortgage would have been good as a security for the $500 even if the bond had never been given.â€Â  (emphasis supplied).Â  The Nichols Court went on to state:

	What effect did the bar of the note by the statute of limitations have upon the debt evidenced by the note and also secured by the mortgage? It is well settled that the effect of the statute is only to take away the remedy, and not to extinguish the debt. When a security is barred the debt is not thereby necessarily discharged. 
	Wilson v. Kelly, 16 S. C. 216. The rule that the discharge of the debt is a discharge of the mortgage has no application when the debt is merely discharged by the statute of limitations or a discharge in bankruptcy. . . 
	
	Though the debt be barred, the lien may be enforced.Â  The fact that a debt secured by a mortgage is barred by a statute of limitations, does not necessarily, or as a general rule, extinguish the mortgage security or prevent the maintaining an action to enforce it.â€ 2 Jones 
	Mort., Â§ 1204 and notes.Â  This is the general rule, and we see no reason founded in principle why it should not be adopted here.

Nichols, 18 S.C. 473.Â   
A creditor shall not have two satisfactions for the same debt, but there is no inconsistency in his pursuing two remedies.Â  If one produces satisfaction, that is a bar to the other.Â  A mortgage is a specific lien, and a judgment is a general lien.Â  Both may be consistently pursued, until the debt is satisfied.Â  Satterwhite v. Kennedy, 3 Strob. 459 (1849).Â 
 
We hold that Lighting Galleries may pursue a foreclosure action notwithstanding its judgment against Lever was extinguished by virtue of the statute of limitations.Â  The order of the Master-in-Equity is reversed.
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  This matter was certified from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  
 
[2] Â Judgment liens on real estate continue for ten years.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-35-810 (1976).Â  
 
[3] Â Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-3-360, â€œ[a]ny person who is indebted by mortgage on real estate may apply to the presiding judge or any court of general sessions and common pleas to be held in the county in which the mortgage on real estate is recorded for a rule to show cause why satisfaction must not be entered thereon.â€
[4]Â  Lighting Galleries was not, at the time, seeking to foreclose on the property.Â Â  However, the property has significantly increased in value recently due to SCDOT wishing to purchase the property at a price of $15,000 per acre.Â  Another party has also recently expressed interest in purchasing the remainder of the mortgaged property.Â  Additionally, although Lighting Galleries was initially a fourth mortgage holder, only two mortgages currently exist on the property.

title: Office of Regulatory Staff v. SCPSC
description: Appellants challenged the Public Service Commissionâ€™s decisions regarding the establishment and implementation of the South Carolina Universal Service Fund.  The Court affirmed in part and reversed in part the trial courtâ€™s conclusion that the Public Service Commissionâ€™s decisions are supported by substantial evidence in the record.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Office of Regulatory Staff Appellant,
				v.
				South Carolina Public Service Commission, South Carolina Telephone Association, and Verizon South, Inc., Respondents.
			
		
	



	
		
			
				South Carolina Cable Television Association and Southeastern Competitive Carriers Association, Appellants,
				v.
				South Carolina Public Service Commission, South Carolina Telephone Association, and Verizon South, Inc. Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26354
Heard October 9, 2003 - Filed June 25, 2007Â Â  

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


	
		
			
				Florence P. Belser, of Office of Regulatory Staff, Frank R. Ellerbe, III and Bonnie D. Shealy, both of Robinson, McFadden, and Moore, of Columbia, for Appellants.
				F. David Butler, of South Carolina Public Service Commission, M. John Bowen, Jr., Margaret M. Fox, Robert T. Bockman, all of McNair Law Firm, P.A., of Columbia, and Steven W. Hamm, of Richardson Plowden Carpenter & Robinson, of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	


JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  Appellants, the Consumer Advocate for the State of South Carolina,[1] South Carolina Cable Television Association (SCCTA) and Southeastern Competitive Carriers Association (SECCA) bring this action challenging the Public Service Commissionâ€™s (Commission) implementation of the Universal Service Fund (USF).Â  The trial court concluded the Commissionâ€™s decisions regarding the State USF are supported by substantial evidence in the record.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The concept of a USF originated when the United States Congress passed the Telecommunications Act of 1996, 47 U.S.C. Â§ 609 (2002). Â The Telecommunications Act was intended, in part, to promote an initiative of â€œuniversal service.â€Â  Congress hoped that a nationwide telecommunications policy of â€œuniversal serviceâ€ would ensure access to basic telephone service at affordable rates for all Americans.[2] Â Congress did so by mandating that the new system of universal service be â€œexplicit,â€ i.e., not dependent upon implicit subsidies. Â 47 U.S.C. Â§ 254(e) (2002). Â The Telecommunications Act provides â€œ[e]very telecommunications carrier that provides interstate telecommunications services shall contribute, on an equitable and nondiscriminatory basis, to the specific, predictable, and sufficient mechanisms established by the Commission to preserve and advance universal service.â€ Â 47 U.S.C. Â§ 254(d) (2002).Â  In furthering the goal of nondiscriminatory universal service, Congress gave the states authority to adopt approaches for encouraging universal service. 
 
With the enactment of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 58-9-280(E) (Supp. 2006), the South Carolina General Assembly authorized the Commission to establish a USF for South Carolina. Â The Commission held three proceedings to address implementation strategies for the fund. Â The first proceeding established the size of the USF as directed by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 58-9-280(E).Â  In re Proceeding to Establish Guidelines for an Intrastate Universal Service Fund, Or. No. 97-753 (S.C. Pub. Serv. Commn. Sept. 3, 1997). Â The second proceeding determined the appropriate cost models and sizing of South Carolinaâ€™s USF.[3]Â  In re Proceeding to Establish Guidelines for an Intrastate Universal Service Fund, Or. No. 98-322 (S.C. Pub. Serv. Commn. May 6, 1998).Â  The Commission selected a forward-looking cost proxy model for non-rural companies and the Benchmark Cost Proxy Model as the state forward-looking cost model for BellSouth, GTE, and Sprint/United.Â  The Commission adopted the South Carolina Telephone Coalitionâ€™s (SCTC) embedded cost model for rural local exchange carriers.[4] Â In the third proceeding, the Commission addressed various outstanding issues relating to the implementation of the fund.[5]Â  In re Proceeding to Establish Guidelines for an Intrastate Universal Service Fund, Or. No. 2001-419 (S.C. Pub. Serv. Commn. June 6, 2001).
Appellants now challenge the Commissionâ€™s findings arising out of these proceedings. 
 
ISSUES

	
		
			I. 
 
			Did Appellants bring a timely 
			appeal of Commission Orders 98-322, 97-753, and 97-942[6]? 
			
 
		
		
			II.
			Is the USF, as established and 
			implemented by the Commission, â€œspecific, predictable and 
			sufficientâ€ in accordance with Section 254(f) of the Federal 
			Telecommunications Act and does the fund comply with S.C. Code Ann. 
			Â§ 58-9-280(E)(4)? 

 
		
		
			 
			Is Section 254(f) of the Federal Telecommunications Act violated because the State USF burdens federal universal support mechanisms? 
			
 
		
		
			III.  
 
			Does the State USF bar 
			competitive entry in violation of Section 253 of the Federal 
			Telecommunications Act?  

 
		
		
			IV.  
 
			Does the State USF fail to match 
			costs and revenues in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 58-9-280(E)? 

 
		
		
			V.   
			
			Did the Commission allocate 25% 
			of network costs to federal jurisdiction, and if the Commission did not make such an allocation, did it violate FCC regulations?
 
		
		
			VI. 
			Does the evidence in the record 
			support the Commissionâ€™s finding that intrastate access charges are 
			priced above cost and provide a significant implicit subsidy to 
			basic local service?
		
	

 LAW/ANALYSIS
Â The findings of the Commission are presumptively correct and have the force and effect of law. Â Therefore, the burden of proof is on the party challenging an order of the Commission to show it is unsupported by substantial evidence and the decision is clearly erroneous in view of the substantial evidence on the whole record. Â Heater of Seabrook Inc. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 20, 27 n.4, 503 S.E.2d 739, 742 n.4 (1998).Â  Substantial evidence is something less than the weight of the evidence and the possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C. 430, 432, 319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984).
Because Appellants have failed to prove the Commissionâ€™s implementation of the State USF is clearly erroneous, we affirm.
The Commissionâ€™s orders are meticulous in their factual determinations and decisions regarding the appropriate methods for implementing the State USF.Â  The orders issued by the Commission throughout its consideration of the USF show careful consideration of numerous proposals on the fundâ€™s implementation.Â  See e.g., Or. No. 97-753 (Sept. 3, 1997); Or. No. 97-942 (Dec. 31, 1997); Or. No. 98-322 (May 6, 1998); Or.
